number of helpful: 3,800 of 3,858 people (98%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 22, 2013
												Crusader Kings 2 is a complex grand strategy game.  The most complicated game I've ever played. Be prepared to spend hours and I mean hours confused as hell, looking at youtube, the wiki and forums.   Once it clicks though, it's awesome.  Not for everyone, but its kinda like playing through 'real life' Game of Thrones (there's a game of thrones mod too). You control a land owning character starting on any date between 1066 and 1453 AD (The Old Gods DLC will push this starting date back to 867 if you wish).  You can start as a powerful emperor or a lowly count.  The map you play on is more or less Europe stretching into parts of Asia and Africa.  Your sole goal in the game is to keep your bloodline going (and I believe holding land).  Other than that, there isn't a win screen, there aren't defined goals, its open ended, you play until 1453AD and then the game ends (save exportable to Europa Universalis 4 to continue your game with the purchase of a DLC).  You get a 'score', but that is just a rough estimate on how prestigious and pious your bloodline was.  It's quite possible to have 400 years of super rewarding gameplay without getting a high score.  This is a trend you will see me developing on and is a big part of what makes CKII so awesome.That's kinda hard to grasp, but it is less awkward than it sounds.  The goals sort of present themselves naturally.  You don't often sit there with no idea what to do (again, once you understand the game), you kind of always have something you're working towards.  For a first time player this is usually just become as powerful as possible, i.e. aquire land, become a king, then become an emperor and expand your empire.  If you're an advanced player you can set your own crazy goals, roleplay, or do other things to spice up the game.The game runs in 'real time', with a day going by a few times a minute on normal speed.  You can fast forward and pause.  Most of the time you will indeed be going through various menus.  Arranging marriages, keeping tabs on powerful families, plotting assinations, acquiring territory through political shennigans, keeping your subjects happy, bringing in powerful characters to tutor the children of the realm and hold office, and much more.  You can micromanage to your hearts content, play a more hands off style, or switch between the two.When combat breaks out, it is done by moving stacks of armys around the campaign map, meeting an opposing army will cause a battle.  These really just compose of watching numbers go down, and kills go up, so if you're looking for Total War style combat you arent going to get it here.  Don't be fooled though, many times I've been on the edge of my seat watching these numbers change.  The combat system is quiet nuanced as well. To be the most effective you have many things to consider. Terrain bonuses, attrition penalties, appointing competant commanders from your realm, and more add depth.In all I highly recommend this game to anyone who has played something like Civ or Total War and fancy themself a strategy gamer, is looking for a challenege, and has a lot of patience.  This is kinda the next step you can take into something quite a bit more complicated.  That is the path I took into the game am loving it.The game is still actively having expansions and patches developed for it as of the writing of this review 11/25/2013.Full disclosure:  Your reviewer has not quite finished a playthrough yet but am close.  I have 120 hours playtime. I own the dlcs The Old Gods, Legacy of Rome, and the Europa Universalis 4 save converter.  I solely purchased EU4 because of how much I enjoyed my crusader kings 2 game and wanted to continue playing my empire, I haven't even played it yet.Also: Don't buy for full price.  Even though it is worth it, getting the game and all the dlc all at full price is pretty expensive. The base game is often on sale or in bundles.This is my first steam review so if you think this is helpful give the thumbs up and I'll do some more reviews.  Hope you enjoyed reading.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												*Update* So good I nominated for an award!Word of warning when buying this, it will will ruin all other strategy games!I was a big Civilization fan and whilst it isn't really far to compare the two (they are wildly different in many ways) going back to something like Civ now seems like a huge leap back in terms of depth. The politics, emergent story and shear possibility of genuine scheming in Crusader Kings 2 make other dilpomacy games almost a joke. Once you've conspired to kill a duke with the help of his wife and the hope of triggering a civil war to potentially swing in the favour of your first born heir as your final legacy, nothing will offer the same devious pleasure in other games.By all means try the demo, but don't be scared off by the amount of information. Whilst great, the interface is certainly intimidating at first, but the tool tips are excellently written for just about every button. Just take your time and don't worry about losing to much at first, just mess around and it will soon come to you. This is the type of game that makes you want to write down your stories just to share with other people. Like that time I murdered my own inbred daughter because she was in a plot with my uncle to kill me! Beat that!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Easily one of the best games I've had the fortune of playing. A grand stragey, which rather than being abstracted out to the extent of Civ or Europa Universalis, allows you to take on the role of a head of state (or, head of county or duchy) and do essentially what you like. Want to conquer Britain? Do it! Want to sit as a count for 400 years? Do it! Want to overthrow the Holy Roman Empire? Well... Good luck.Although the core game only allows Christian rulers (thanks ahyangyi!)  to be played, Sword of Islam adds Islamic groups, The Republic adds republics, The Old Gods adds Pagans and Sons of Abraham adds the Jewish kingdom. Each provides a new style of gameplay, distinct from the others.Grand strategy at its finest, though frustratingly hard at times.

												I bought this game in a Humble Bundle package and activated it on May 14th of 2015. In the 566 days since that day, according to Steam, I have logged 1310 hours in this game. This means that 9.6% of my life since adding this game to my Steam library has been playing Crusader Kings 2. If you adjust to exclude 7 hours of sleep per day, 13.6% CK2 time. If you adjust to exclude a 40 hour work week, this figures to 20.5%.Since installing this game, it has occupied one fifth of my waking non-work life.These are all facts. Hard, sobering, mathematical facts. Some day, if I stop playing CK2, perhaps I will reflect upon these facts. But until then, I'll be conquering the world.

content:
Posted: February 22
Product received for free
												So I think it's about that time when I actually review this game. I've played it off steam for more than 300 hours and about 1500 hours on steam, so it's fair to say I've experienced just about all the bugs, highs and lows, DLCs' and changes to the game's mechanics through the never-ending patches on Paradox' end. I will preface this by saying I'm a history nerd and a complete and utter sucker for the medieval era. I'm a nostalgic dreamer who always used to dream about a game that was dynasty (family) focused, as opposed to the total warfare/dominate the universe-type game. So when I got this game as a gift, it was like someone had created the game for me. It's my go to when I just want to pass time and see whatever my Swedish countess or Scottish duke are up to. The level of micromanagement is ridiculous. I love it. But it's borderline insane. Go through the tutorials of the game, and you'll find yourself lost with a sensation of you might know what you did wrong. Don't go through the tutorials, and you might as well be trying to fill in for Slash at a concert, when the most experience you've had playing a guitar was looking at a banjo through a shop's window. It's intense. In the beginning I lost whole countries to distant relatives in other countries and was scratching my head, but eventually I got the hang of it. I think everyone can play this game, but you have to be prepared to put in a lot of effort and willingness to learn its mechanics. And then after that, there are lesser things to learn, such as your wife trying to kill you because you had a sweet dalliance with her sister. Or perhaps the fact that leading your own troops could result in the unfortunate event of you losing your life, and your 3-year old, imbecilic son inheriting your entire kingdom. There's always more to learn, no matter how much you play this game - its excitement will last you a long time. I love this game because of its neverending possibility for replayability. No game will ever be the same. You can customize your characters with an inexpensive DLC (get the DLCs - at least "The old Gods" and a few more. They add so much to the game), and you can create the basis of your new game with a new objective. The word sandbox is key, because in this world, you are not only the lord of your demesne, but of your own fate. Do you want to take that neighbouring county? Or do you just want to keep your family strong and safe, provide good husbands for your daughters? Maybe your king has been getting on your nerves and you want to gather allies and usurp his throne? This medieval world is all yours - if you have the gold, skill and time. On the downside of things, I think CK2 is worth €40, but for a four-year old game it's on the steeper side. It's frequently on sale though. Add it to your wishlist and wait; you can snatch it up for a fraction of its original price. I've enjoyed this game so much and had so many angry, funny and downright amazing moments. Wars I thought I'd lose have turned and I've won entire kingdoms. I've romanced my way through entire courts to get women to join my plots to kill people. The level of intrigue, surprises, horrors, joys and entertaining moments are endless. Oh, and...I seduced the pope once. As a gay king. 10/10.

												Crusader Kings II is in my opinion one of the best strategy games out there. Do you like medieval times? Times when you could call your vassals forth and fight against the invader? Or against an ally? Your brother? Your sister? Your cat? Then shut up and give them money!You can play as the brutal vikings and sack the coastal regions, or an Irish nobleman who wants to reunify the broken country, or a republic? Do you want to be the prince of Persia? Ok jokes on the side, additional content has been recently announced, the game is constantly being updated by the devs, and they are truly working hard on it. You have a save file converter to continue the adventures of your dinasty on EUIV, another grand strategy game. Start out small, and try to make your family name shine! You can even customize your rulerz (an additional dlc though). Yes this is a fanboy review.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												My friend and I decided to play a multiplayer game of Crusader Kings II earlier. Never in my life have I ever been more frightened in a video game. Let me explain.My friend and I decided to be counts in different kingdoms and empires. My character was a little interesting.First Name: 12Last Name: ISISGoal: Spread my "seed" to all corners of the worldLocation: EnglandRank: Count of KentI had set the goal of spreading my "seed" all over the world because I thought it would make for some interesting gameplay, and boy did something interesting happen.The game started off normal, my friend was in the Holy Roman Empire as a Duke, and I was in the nearby province of Kent in England, not far from the border of the Holy Roman Empire so we were both well within diplomatic range. I started to spread my "seed" by seducing as many women as I could. I tended to seduce the women who had high rankings, such as the Empress of the Holy Roman Empire, the Queen of England, Queen of France, and other higher ranking women. My fertility was well above average, and basically any woman I seduced would have a child.After a couple of decades having passed, my friend had become Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, and I spread my seed to almost every major kingdom and empire in diplomatic range (little did my friend know, he was actually playing as my illegitimate child that I had with the Empress of the Holy Roman Empire). You could always tell which children were mine based on their names. Most of my children had the most ridiculous names like, "THANKS OBAMA" or "Nigerian Prince Simulator". But, there was one child I had that would cause a lot of problems for everyone. His name was "Forgot the Condom"."Forgot the Condom" was a normal child at first. He grew up till the age of 6 relatively normal, but then something went horribly wrong. While trying to seduce more women, I got a notification in the game. This is essentially what the notification said: "My son 'Forgot the Condom' is not like other children. He does not scream or cry or even get upset, but he observes the world with keen interest. This morning, he burst into bubbling laughter when a cook cut his hand badly and there was blood everywhere. Animals do not like him and he makes a strange buzzing sound when near other children. Courtiers whisper 'demon spawn' and the servants have started to avert their eyes and make covert signs to ward off evil." After telling my friend about the event (he had a lot more experience in the game than me), he immediately mentioned that I should stop whatever I was doing and kill my child. My friend exact words were, "Your son is a demon, you have to kill him or it will be too late.""Too late?" I asked. My friend remained silent. At the time, the only way to kill your own child was to imprision them and execute them. So, I decided I would try to do that. Well, whenever I tried to imprison "Forgot the Condom", he ended up escaping and fleeing the country. I explain this to my friend and he tells me, "We have to kill him, somehow." At the time, neither my friend nor I knew about the character search tool in the game, so we had to manually find "Forgot the Condom" in all of the provinces. We looked for 30 minutes, and could not find him. After we finished searching, we decided to continue with the game as normal. "Let's just hope nothing bad happens", my friend exclaimed.Five years pass, and I get a notification. It reads: "My dear daughter 'SWAGYOLO420NOSCOPE" must have suffered a stroke in her sleep last night. She was found drooling in bed, one eye bloodshot, mumbling about a small monster that stabbed her in the eye before it ran off. There are dark rumours about the so called 'demon child', my son 'Forgot the Condom', again... As always when something terrible happens, she does seem inordinately happy." I thought we had been rid of "Forgot the Condom", but he was back, with a vengeance.I tried finding "Forgot the Condom" again in all of the provinces near me, but I could not find him.Another year passes, my son "URLUCKYIDIDNTABORTU" dies. Then my daughter, "6 Salads" dies. My son, "Taco Tuesday" dies. At this point I realized, "Forgot the Condom" is killing all of my children. I entirely dedicated to finding and killing him. I'm looking around for him, and he is killing all of my children. We look for him for 2 years in game, when my friend says something."HOLY♥♥♥♥♥♥ I FOUND HIM!""WHAT WHAT, WHERE IS HE?" I ask."Holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ he.... he""What? What's wrong?""He is the ♥♥♥♥ING POPE."I immediately check to see if he is right. My son... my son, "Forgot the Condom" is the ♥♥♥♥ing Pope. My friend and I start to freak out, "How the hell did he become the Pope?!?!" "What do we do?" "HOW DID WE NOT NOTICE THIS BEFORE?!?!?!"Immediately we start a plot to kill "Forgot the Condom". We have to kill him before it's too late. We have to kill him before it's too late. We have to kill him before it's too late.We had 167% plot power, we were going to kill him, but then the worst thing happen. I get a notification: "My dear son 'Ebola Paitent 0' has died." So, what is so special about Ebola Paitent 0? Well, Ebola Paitent 0 was the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, aka my friend. My demon child "Forgot the Condom" killed my friend. At this point in the game, the entirety of my children and lineage, the ISIS family line, had been completely wiped out. Except for one person, except for me, "12, 12 of the family ISIS". I could no longer kill my son because you cannot plot against your children, I was stuck. I had no where to go. I was going to die, the ISIS family line was going to die. I struggled to find any way to kill the Pope, my friend could not start a plot because his new character was a child. We had nowhere to turn. We were out of options.Eventually, the worst came, "Forgot the Condom" killed me in my sleep. I was dead, the legendary "12 of ISIS" was dead.The game ended. I had no heirs, and I was eliminated from the game. The game was also hosted by me so it ended for my friend as well."WHAT THE ♥♥♥♥ was that?" my friend said. I didn't even say anything. A few minutes pass, we were staring at the defeat screen the entire time."We must remember this in some way." I explained. "We must remember '12 of ISIS' and 'Forgot the Condom'. We need to memoralize them forever." "How do we do that?" my friend asks."I don't know, but we must remember them. They are legends and must never be forgotten."TL; DR The game is ♥♥♥♥ing amazing.

content:
Posted: December 23, 2016
 Everything You Need To Know  (She just want to smoke and create the definitive review for CK2, I said, "Girl, that's all that we do.")  That Good Good  Good News:  The game is great and endlessly replayable. Pros beat the cons. Stop reading this and buy it, nerds.   Good News:   You don't have to force it. If learning the game isn't immediately fun, stop. You're not missing enjoyment later. Good News:   Losing is fun!  History has its eyes on you. Good News:   Winning is fun! There are easy starts for first time players. Cornwall 1066 is great place to hide.. Good News:   The Game of Thrones Mod is proof that life is worth living. Look how lucky we are to be alive right now. Good News:   The Conclave features getting roasted in the negative reviews can now be disabled, mostly.  Good News:   You're smart enough to succeed even if those Conclave features couldn't be disabled. I appreciate you, a lot. Good News:   Civilization is a strategy board game. If you'd prefer a historical rulership sim, this is it. You're home. Good News:   Most of the DLC is unimportant. Plus, it's easier to learn by starting with the base game anyway.  DLC Importance The base game is playing a Christian Crusader King. Most game features cater to them. The Holy Land awaits.DLC releases are accompanied by free updates, so the current base game alone is still better than the base game at launchDLC rulers (Indians/etc) are advanced variations on the rulers in the base game. No need to buy them until way later.For example, Vikings are a blast, but only if you can appreciate how they're different from normal kings.You won't enjoy these rulers if you don't at least somewhat enjoy the basic ones, so, again, DLC not a major key upfront.DLC rulers are not needed to play the game as it was intended. They explore playing the game as it was not intended. It's not "You want to play Super Mario Bros as Luigi? Fifteen bucks."It's more "For your 1000th playthrough of Super Mario Bros, would you like to pay to play as the Goomba Caliph?" DLC Cost Remember, the game had plenty of people hooked before the DLC features existed.Buy the DLC you want over time. I had to do that, they weren't out yet!If you still like the game after 100 hours of play, buy The Old Gods. If you still like it 100 hours later, buy Way of Life and Legacy of Rome.After 300 hours grab Sword of Islam. (And Ruler Designer and Customization if you want to get creative.)Snag Conclave and Charlemagne on hour 400, and then you're done.Buy Way of Life upfront if you want. Or add these DLCs in a different order or at a different rate. It doesn't matter.They're not starter material, they're meant to add a fresh spin on a game you want more of. Game is fantastic, but maybe some of these nitpicks are dealbreakers/I don't know your life/You do you   Bad News:  Tutorial is not helpful. Check YouTube or just feel it out. If your hype dies, stop playing. I stayed hyped. Bad News:  This game's multiplayer isn't good but the real problem is them even putting it in at all. Games can take weeks! Bad News:  Bugs. Enough to make Ironman (where console commands and manual saving are disabled) unappealing. Bad News:  Like other detailed projects (think Skyrim, Fallout), it's gonna crash. Mods turn this up to 11. It's worth it. Bad News:  The combat system is functional but uncomplicated. This is not Total War. Don't push it in that direction. Bad News:  Unlike the rest of the game, ideal army composition is not something you'll figure out by playing. Bad News:   Plenty of names from plenty of languages and zero pronunciation hints. Bad News:  Feudal rulers were not absolute monarchs. This can be difficult. You will be tempted to mod this out. Don't. Bad News:  The Game of Thrones Mod is so damn good. The base game is comparatively lacking in roleplay elements. Bad News:  The Game of Thrones Mod is so damn good, but you're better off waiting until you're a seasoned CK2 veteran. Bad News:  Occasionally, you may feel like you arbitrarily have less control over your character than you should. Bad News: AI is stubborn, impatient, insecure, and can't see the big picture. Bad News:  AI will be equally mad about being harmed and about being denied some extremely unfeasible goal. Bad News:  Your council gets upset at your heir when you die for... not being you. Bad News:  There's an education event where you can make your kid functional if you harm yourself in return. It's never worth it, and ignoring it is impossible because... Bad News:  This event can actually be gamed, as all mentors can receive it. Simply make a rival mentor a kid, then watch him become a inefficient mess. Unfortunately, this can also wreck valuable NPCs or  anyone whoever mentors anyone . Bad News:  AI never considers that the situation they don't like is still their best option. They always prefer change. Bad News:  Loyalty is not measured separately from opinion. The ramifications of this will become obvious the more you play Bad News:  You lose too much control over your children if they're not in your court. Bad News:  Similarly, you have no power to intervene on their behalf if you couldn't do the same if they weren't family. Bad News:  Split custody issues exist but there's no way of predicting some of them and no mechanic for fixing any of them. Bad News: : When you die and become your heir, you're not given context or explanation for what they've been up to, even though you're now them.  Bad News:  Some of your council resigns when your heir takes over, but they don't mind being immediately rehired.... what? Bad News:  Your heirs will sabotage the stability of your realm even thought it will hurt them later when they're in charge. Bad News: Enemy rulers sometimes continue to rule from places you've already conquered, making them uncapturable. Bad News:  No boat combat. Not a big deal, but the cost of getting and maintaining boats is a lot for just a troop transport.  Bad News:  All of inner Africa south of Muslim-held West Africa feels poorly thought out.  Wack Issues   Bad News:  The game map has grown. India will make your game slower even if you never go there.  Bad News:  You're never going to India. Bad News:  Your laptop will heat up. Blame India. The Game of Thrones mod similarly is plagued by Essos. Bad News:  They chose adding India over strengthening the base game. It has no reason to be here. Bad News:  Norse and Muslim rulers are key to Europe, so their expansions helped the base game. India? Not so much. Bad News: : I just don't get why India is in this game. It adds a huge problem for weaker PCs for a minimal payoff. Bad News:  Dealing with raiders becomes an annoying chore if you control many coastal provinces. Bad News:  Adventurers/Rebels (can be disabled) get bizarrely huge armies. You'll understand when you see it. The Wackest Issue (In-game) Costs are laughably expensive and not relative to each other. The different random events where you can spend money on things often require a literal king's ransom. Some mundane costs are equal to a month's income of Europe's largest kingdom. It is frustratingly nonsensical.  Small Issue w/ Bad Vibes The ruler designer, which is a paid add-on, will not let you create an unbalanced character even if you aren't playing in Ironman for Achievements.This is absurd and an actual legitimate DLC grievance. You can futz around with the console to try to fix it, but it's not a perfect solution. Mod fix is available. Vote Dukakis

content:
Posted: January 20, 2015
Incest simulator ?This is the title that many jokingly have given this game on the internet. However this far from what the game is, can you perform incest, yes, however the deepth and dynamics goes far beyond mere incestual relations. Main purpose or goal?You are the head of a dynasty, at the beginning of the game, you can choose which dynasty, and who within that dynasty that you want to play as. Do you want to take control of one of the powerful rulers of the mighty Karling dynasty? Or do you want to repeat history by trying to bring a small count in Switzerland from an obscure family known as Habsburg to their glory, as Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire, and spread the Habsburg from there on. With the customize ruler DLC you expand you game a thousandth-fold, you will have to power to not only choose who you want to play as, but you can create you whole new dynasty and ruler. Want a genius hunchback who rules over the Arabian Empire? Do you want to try and backstab your way to the top of the Byzantine Empire with a powerful spy? It is up to you!There is one indicator on how well you have done, that is your Score which the game at the end compare with other great historical dynasties. You increase your score by having rulers with high prestige and piety, but also having other dynasty members in high positions, will generate prestige to your dynasty, giving newborn a higher starting position in life, when it comes to their prestige.There are so many DLCs!Many seem to get overwhelmed by the amount of DLCs this game has, however many of those are cosmetic DLCs, adding other graphics or sounds to the game. The main DLCs that expand gameplay are:I will rank them, with the top being the most important expansion to get first, by my own opinion.Ruler Designer - This will enable you to create your own ruler, only your imagination will limit the replayability of the game.Legacy of Rome - This expansion not only gives more deepth to the Orthodox rulers of the Byzantine, and greek cultures, it also provides new game mechanics, such as military retinues. (Also allow the possibility for castrating and blinding prisoners playing as a ruler of the Byzantine culture group)The Old Gods - This enable you to play the game from 867 CE, and also make Pagans and Zoroastrian rulers playable.Sword of Islam - Makes muslims playable, as The Old Gods each unique religion has its own mechanics.Sons of Abraham - Adds more deepth to the abrahamic faiths and also Judaism. Heresies for religions are also possible.The Republic - Want to try out the merchant life of Venice? With this DLC that will be possible, take control of a patrician family, amass wealth and control the trade zones around the shores of the known world.Charlemagne - Introduces a new starting time, at 769 CE, gives you the option to create custom Kingdoms and Empires.Rajas of India - Allows for control of the Indian rulers. Way of Life - Focus the life of your ruler towards certain areas of his life, want to became a great hunter to catch the fable white bear? Or became the greatest architech in the whole realm?Customization Pack - Customize your ruler ingame, change the beard, hair style, even the dynasty name or shield.Sunset Invasion - If you want to add an extra level of crazy to your game, only recommended for veteran players of CK2, what if the Aztec discovered Europe first? And decided to invade?Save Game converter - If you own Europa Universalis IV and want to continue your saga from CK2, this DLC will enable you to export your CK2 game into EU IV.All the other DLCs are cosmetical.Mods!Crusader Kings 2 has more mods, that will expand your game, one of the more popular mods is a total conversion into a Game of Thrones universe. Where you can encounter spoilers from the series, but it will also make you play out the stories in George R.R. Martin's universe in another direction, should Tyrion Lannister have the Iron Throne? Learning curve?It has a steep learning curve, and the ingame tutorial only scratches the surface of possibilities. I would recommend picking up the game, and play with a friend online, or experiment as a count in Ireland. But when you get a hang on it, it will grab you, and pull you deeper into a world of intrigue, murder, war, romance, and much more. In an forever going struggle for power over the realm, and the world.

Posted: January 23
												As a northern Jarl. My ambition was to unify the Northern people, as my father had did before me. I set out and subjecated my neighbours. Soon Norway, Sweden, Denmark and half of Finland was mine. My most favored and ONLY son, a true prodigy of my blood line; did me proud when he said he wanted to service in the Byzantine Varangian Guard.With tears in the back of my throat, my heart beating with pride as I saw the ship sail away to a golden sunset. Many months passed without a word from my son. I had many daughters in his absence. I ruled and I went and conquered the Saxon kingdom. The south was open for the taking.I reccive words after putting down a foolish rebellion. That sails bearing the family standard. A Golden tree on a field of green. I made prepartions in the hall. Odin be praised! My son was finally home! As the doors slams open and a man I bearly recognize as my son steps into the light. He seems ashamed despite my smiles. After the feast, I told him it was time for him to take on a wife and make a family.Dark became the hall when he told me the news of deeds in the Byzantine Varangian Guard. Sleeping with one of the wifes of the Emperor. He had lost his manhood. I had not gotten my son back... but another daughter.I told my housecarls to seize the creature before me and put him in chains. He did not scream nor complain as my men dragged him away. I have to respect him for that.The day came when it was time for blot, so I personally was the one who placed the blade at my former son's throat and made the leathal blow. The Jarls of the Kingdom, seemed pleased at this. But I knew that behind their false smiles that their resentment of me was now higher without an heir. I had only daughters.Who would have known that my sons life was connected to my own. Bloodlines are like trees. Roots are the ancestors, the trunk are you and the branches are the children. Now without the branches my line has come to an end.As I see the army of my wifes brother come over the hills eager to see my head detached from my body, I can only think what will happen to my memory. Will someone remember this bloodline? Or will we fade into oblivion? Even so, I will see my son in Valhalla. And there we will feast with the Aesir. Odin see me!This is my story.What will be yours?This game is worth playing.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2015
												If you care about the amount of gameplay you get for your money at all, this game probably rates higher than any other game. (Last I read, the average player had over 500 hours on this game.) Crusader Kings II is a strategic game where you spend most of your time looking at a big map of Europe cut into little counties, but it is drastically different from a game like Medieval II: Total War.  Whereas in those games, every nation had rigid boundaries and an entire nation was a distinct, unified entity, Crusader Kings II focuses upon the feudal system of governance, and especially its hereditary system of succession.You are not a nation, you are an extended family through the ages.  You may start as King of England, but lose the throne in a succession war, only to wind up inheriting the Kingdom of France, instead.  It is a game of political machinations more than warfare.You can't just declare war whenever you want to, you need to, by hook or by crook, manage to get a claim to that land you want to invade.  Battles are relatively quick and hands-off (play that Total War if you want to manage the troops directly) but it's the space between wars that makes the game interesting.  To get that claim, you probably need to find some way to get the princess of that land in your bed (or your son's bed), and it's this medieval bloodline plotting that make up the meat of the game.  For that matter, you don't necessarily need to declare war to gain land - just marry into the family that succeeds a throne, and make sure that, one way or the other, your chosen heir also manages to be the chosen heir of a target kingdom, and the kingdoms will be unified upon the death of your current character and the current king of the target land. Likewise, just because you gain land doesn't mean you can keep it.  You need to delegate land out, and succession laws can fragment your kingdom so much that you see hard-conquered lands slip out of your grasp by inheritence without your consent.  EDIT: And since writing this, Conclave has come out to add complexities to keeping your nobles in line.Worse, while whomever you give land will be quite grateful for the first 20 years of their rule or so, their children will have no gratitude for the gift of land your father gave them, and will likely be burning with ambitions you have to keep in check.  Every few decades, your character ages and dies, and succession wars and civil wars are the primary way the game keeps your over-arching ambitions in check.  Rather than letting a large empire mean that no external threat can challenge you, and no internal threats exist, the larger you become, the less vulnerable you are to external threats, but the more vulnerable you are to internal ones. You spend more and more time trying to find a way to bludgeon the rebellious nobles and religious minorities into line.If you get tired of games of Total War, and don't bother completing them because, once you are the strongest power on the map, there's nothing to do but steamroll everything else that stands in your path, then CK2 is a great remedy to this.  (You can still make a world-spanning super-empire, but it's much more interesting to try to keep it when the owners of that land still fight you when you plant your flag there than to just have them mutely pay taxes to you and have assumed loyalty to your cause.)It's a game that's just hard and realistic enough to make the things you do actually feel like you're thumbing your nose at history.  You can play an Irish earl, rise to High King of Ireland, and conquer England.  Or play as the West Africans, and conquer the Muslims and convert them to your pagan faith.  Being a norse viking that captures the pope and sacrifices him to Odin is always fun.  (And nabs the Holy Smoke! achievement.) And if you do it with an unbroken line of Viking empresses, all the better.Mods are also a high point: Play the Elder Kings mod, based upon the Elder Scrolls, and conquer Cyrodiil and beyond as an immortal or vampire, using magicks to summong hordes of demons when under threat. There's an A Game of Thrones mod, as well, and mods to turn the game into something like a space 4X game.  DLC still comes out for the game, as well.  While more than a little annoying to be nickled and dimed, the trickle of new content keeps the game fresh and new achievements are meaningful challenges, requiring players to take up historic underdogs to rise to glory.  Getting a full board of achievements is extraordinarily difficult, but enjoyable for the challenge they provide.  Compare this to Activision, Ubisoft, or EA, where you buy iterations of the same game every year, and throwing down $10 for another year's worth of life in a game is well worth the price.

Posted: March 26, 2014
												I recommend the living ♥♥♥♥ out of this game.Seriously, if you like grand-scale strategy games, but want something with a deeper "roleplaying" element in it, this game is right up your alley. Ultimate goal of the game is to advance your familial dynasty to the top of medieval Europe's feudal pecking order through war, diplomacy, subterfuge, and all sorts of other scandalous medieval shenanigans. You play the game through your character, who experiences text-based events occasionally that you, the player, must choose how he reacts to. You will mobilize and lead armies, fall in love, conquer foreign (and-not-so-foreign nations), marry your cousins and breed your children using the power of eugenics to secure your family's power in future generations -- though not necessarially in that order.Fun♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10/10 just like the real medieval times.

												11/10 - Would become Earl Cadoc of Cornwall again.CK2 – The Misfortune SimulatorThe Life of Cadoc of CornwallWilliam the Conqueror succeeds in his invasion of England, which is good as Harold was good for nothing. In his wisdom, William decided to create the Duchy of Cornwall and NOT make me the Duke. I remain a lowly Earl.Start plot to assassinate the current Duke of Cornwall, I want that position. Nobody likes me enough to join it. End of plot.The only guy who actually liked me a lot and had great traits, my Chancellor, today died of depression. The only two suitable replacements look more like the living embodiment of the Seven Deadly Sins. I chose one of them with reluctance.My wife is pregnant. Hopefully it'll be a boy!My first daughter, whom is to be my heir, refuses to learn any of my traits. To this day, she remains Ambitious, and only Ambitious.The child is born. It's a girl.And to add the icing on the bitter Cake of Feudal Disappointment, my loving wife died giving birth to said child.Got married again!Wife insisted on becoming a Spymaster. Funny, both my wives have been Spymasters...Treason! Rebellious scum have risen in Cornwall, and I am besieged. According to someone of little importance in my Council, this rebellion only had a 6.5% chance of actually happening. I should buy a ticket for the Great Monarch Lottery.Duke Arsewipe of Cornwall has aided me in removing the rebellious scum that infested my lands. I still hate him.Praise be to God! A plague of Typhus has swept Cornwall. Perhaps Duke Arsewipe shall be given a painful and miserable death.Duke Arsewipe lives...yay.My wife is pregnant, I hope it's a boy. I'm sure the saying goes “Second time lucky”.Apparently the saying goes “Third time lucky”, and I am now the only man in a house of my wife and four daughters.Instead of consoling me, today my Court Chaplain came to me to spread heresy. Naturally, I imprisoned him.My Steward is dead, and there are no candidates to replace him. I now spend a portion of my day keeping the chair warm.Today, I learned that Duke Arsewipe had a previous wife who tragically died of Camp Fever. I'm still unsure as to what the hell kind of name 'Hungifu' is for a woman. Those weird Anglo-Saxons.My wife is once again pregnant. Since this is the 'third time', maybe I will be in luck.My first daughter has married the son of the King of Denmark. We are now far more Prestigious, and Denmark are now my allies.It's a boy! Cador is born!My eldest daughter has given birth to a daughter.My second eldest daughter has just married the son of the King of Navarra. We now have an alliance with Navarra. Duke Arsewipe better look over his shoulder from now on.My niece has asked me to help her find a suitor to marry. Rather concerning is the fact that someone has put my newborn son on the list. I will choose her someone that isn't related. I decided to hold a marvellous feast, with only the finest food. Unfortunately, I only have one guest. The feast went well.Managed to convince my Bishop, whom was formerly my Court Chaplain, to become a Catholic once again. Upon doing so, I released him from prison.I have started a new plot to kill Duke Arsewipe, and with a little (a lot) of coin, I have convinced two others to join me. At last, my enemy shall die!For whatever reason only known to them, my two supporters backed out without telling me. To add insult to injury, Duke Arsewipe had the nerve to ask me to let a member of his family educate one of MY children!Turned 50 today. Happy Birthday to me...yay.Today, my WIFE discovered that my eldest DAUGHTER is planning to kill my only SON and heir. I think my family has finally hit rock bottom.My wife is pregnant...A boy has been born! This is becoming a big family, hopefully they won't murder each other.Alas, sickness murdered my newborn son.It's been twenty years since Duke Arsewipe became duke, and for some reason, he still insists on breathing more life into his wretched soul. I may be older, but I will outlive him!My wife is pregnant...again. I really need to calm down in my old age.It's a boy. The family seems to be evening out a bit now.I have no idea how I do it, but I've managed to get my wife pregnant again. My Court Chaplain insists I stop these so-called “shenanigans”.I am blessed with another son.Duke Arsewipe has stepped over the line now. He has asked me to allow HIM to educate MY son and heir. May the Devil take him!60 today. I insist upon outlasting Duke Arsewipe!My eldest daughter's husband has died at the age of 31, and the circumstances are very suspicious.My son and heir is now married to the princess of the Holy Roman Empire!My half-brother, Dumnarth, died today. He will be greatly missed.Insulted my wife by calling her gluttonous and a monster when it comes to table manners. I shall not be doing that again.It is done. Duke Arsewipe finally had his last breath on August 1st, 1101 at the age of 69. I can now go to my grave a happy man.At the age of 72, Earl Cadoc of Cornwall died after a period of illness on November 2nd, 1103. He succeeded in his goal of outlasting his mortal enemy.Rest In Peace, Earl Cadoc of Cornwall.

content:
Posted: October 24, 2016
												I suppose that now that I've logged over 1,000 hours playing Crusader Kings 2 I should carve out a little time to say that this is demonstrably my favorite game of all time (by a factor of five, if you're curious).  There are 16,000 other reviews that will give you more details of what's great and what's not about the game, but let me just add that I have never found a game that better simulates  internal  political conflict within a country.  Think about it: you play most "great" strategy games like Civilization, and you'd think that nations were made up of uniform automatons - the worst it gets there is some city riots because you didn't build enough "Happiness" buildings.  In CK2 your vassal rulers are individuals, with their individual ambitions and characteristics, and they can be a real pain to manage - sometimes they fight with one another, sometimes they fight with you, and ultimately it's about who's got the most leverage.  The only difference between CK2 politics and modern democratic politics is that "leverage" in the 12th century is usually counted in swords; besides that, the backstabbing and intriguing is pretty indistinguishable.  A strong king, just like a strong president, is one who dominates their internal foes so that they can in turn dominate their external ones.That simple innovation is what's made this my all-time favorite game, the one I've been coming back to year after year.  Add to that a dedicated modding community that let's you play out the same internal/external conflict in Game of Thrones, Ancient Rome, or Warhammer, and, well, you've got at least a thousand hours of fun ahead of you.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Crusader Kings II is an exceptional game in that no other title will make you feel like a ruler as well as it. You're not just a country, like in other grand strategy games. You are a ruler with qualities, flaws, vices and virtues. You can be a Duke who is a brilliant diplomat with a hunchback, an ugly, stuttering dimwit count, or a mastermind plotter/lesbian queen. (I'm NOT making it up). And you can be all that within in a single playthrough, as you re-incarnate into your heir when you die. You have to be good at managing your realm, but you've got to be even better at managing your dynasty by arranging favourable marriages, assassinate pretenders... It's all very involving and requires a lot of micro-management (which you may or may not like).It's not without flaws: the interface could see much improvement and the game starts to slow down when you become powerful. By slow down, I don't mean that your computer has a hard time coping, I mean that there are many more events that require your constant attention, making things move at a slower pace. To be honest, after several hundred hours, I think I'm a bit burned with the game. And that, even though there are entire DLCs I haven't really explored yet: I have only really played as a Catholic or Muslim ruler, but DLCs let you play as pagans, Orthodoxes, republics...And then there are a couple of Mods that are probably worth exploring as well: "Game of Thrones" and "Tamriel" (from the Elder scrolls series)Still, with so much content and the unbeatable feeling of being an actual Middle-Ages ruler, it's hard to rate CKII anything lower than a 9 out of 10.

												This used to be my favorite game ever. I have hundreds of hours logged into this game. I even loved crusader kings 1. But Paradox has decided to let some no talent idiots take control of the Crusader Kings 2 project. Essentially they have repalced the main development team and the vision of the game has drastically changed. I have almost all the DLC's for this game and have spent quite a bit of money on it and NOW they start ruining it? Instead of giving us new things to conquer or new characters to interact with or new cool things to do they have decided just to make the old things harder and more annoying. Between conclave and the proposed black death dlc the developers are severely limiting game play by injecting annoying, illogical and unrealistic events into the game. People already plotted to rebel and acquire power for themselves but conclave made it easier for them. There were already illnesses that caused quite a bit of devastation in the game so the new DLC is proposed to maximize that already annoying situation. What fun is that going to be?? Well let me tell you it will be about as fun as micromanaging all your vassals is in Conclave. Basically none. The UI and real time mode of game play severely limit micromanagement oppurtunities.I am very unhappy with the direction crusader kings 2 is going with the dlc's and I will no longer be purchasing them. But even that doesn't stop the new jerk developers because they patch in idiotic things like broken retreat into the game whether you like it or not. This is what happens when you don't allow negative feedback on your forums and fill it with bootlicking yes men. They pretty much ban anybody who makes the slightest criticisms of their games on their forums. Don't believe me go and see. Screw you paradox. No more money for you.

content:
Posted: November 18, 2016
												Playing virtually any dynasty in this game, big or small, feels like trying to balance on top of a ball on top of another ball. Just when you hit that sweetspot your leader dies, and you fall and have like 30 seconds to have the new guy get up there and figure out how to not lose his balance or else it's game over; or atleast a gut-wrentching downsize.If you bought the game and can't figure it out, play a small dynasty several times through. I've always been interested in Italian history so I played several games as the Duke of Ferrara starting in the late medieval era (1337ad) who controls only two counties. Starting in 1337ad makes it so your technology, baronies, temples and cities are universally well developed, meaning you can concentrate on learning the rules of medieval rulership and how they apply to the game and acheiving your goals for the playthrough. For your own game, try playing as a few different powerful leaders and then as a few weak ones so that you see the difference in player control over your realm.I've now gone back to 867ad Italy, with the Duke of Tuscany, Adelberto Bonifazi. The king of Italy, a foreign invader from the Karling Dynasty of France is leige to the 5 major Italian duchies, and is moderately respected within Italy. Europe is divided from west to east by three different Karling Kings, and the throne of Italy is up for grabs within their house. It makes for fantastic storytelling of italian unification, or fragmentation (which is more consistant with the history books). Find any dynasty that tugs at your fairytale strings and you'll create the adventure yourself. You compile your own ruleset for winning, and you'll play again and again to get it 'just right'. You are allowed to pick and choose from a wonderful list of histrorical characters from the 760's through the 1300's (more with DLC). You might even find yourself on wikipedia learning about how europe, northern africa and western asia used to work. Once you are briefly educated on succession laws, title claimancy, and holy war you'll be well on your way to taking Rome for the Byzantine empire and converting all Christians to Orthodox and thus resolving the great schism, or perhaps you'll begin as a small vassal, in control of a single county and have your progeny expand and reclaim The Holy Roman Empire. Or maybe you'll just want to keep a small duchy in Italy safe from foreign invasion generation after generation and keep your family safe at all costs. It is at its core a sandbox game. You create the goals, you amend them, the world changes drastically, your position changes, there's an opening, the window closes, alliances are broken, new friends arrive at court to save the day, and eventually you forget what the original goal of winning was to begin with. You watch and contribute to the story as generations of genetic triumphs and failures are constantly bickering, warring, dieing, plotting, changing sides for no good reason, and are also generally trying to make sure you don't have a larger army than they do. Don't forget about all the neighbors, who are convinced that they would be better suited to rule in your lands than you are.There are a thousand pitfalls to success in CK2 as there surely were in the more noble times, so always learn from your mistakes and try again. Use google. And always have enough gold to hire an appropriately sized mercenary army and pay them for 12 months. Always. Eight hour playthroughs that fall because of premature spending will remind you of that. Keep your neighbor rulers in the character watch list, keep a constant eye on beneficial marriages, and constantly scan the character find sheet for potential courtiers that would join your court and could serve as councilmembers. Remember that the safety of the family is top priority, so always be able to defend yourself, be it through your own army, your vassals or your alliance's, but never have a substantially smaller force than the neighbors or vassals. That will spell game over. And lastly, please try to remember at all times that those who cannot remember the past are doomed to repeat it.

content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I will not talk about how Crusader King II compares to other strategy games on the market because it wouldn't be fair to them. You do not compare a Picasso with children drawings from school. Students have to do quick flashy drawings for good grades, and do them as often as they can, with accent on flashy rather than on detail. Crusader Kings II is a game that puts the accent more on detail, quality rather than quantity.The game itelf may feel a bit hard to understand at first, but if you give it a moment of your time, it will surprise you. But buyer be warn, if you just wanna play a game where you plug in, then all you do is fancy easy war TW style, or EUIV, then better avoid CK2. Crusader Kings II requires the player to think, quite a bit actually, and consider choices and plan ahead, sometimes for a few decades. It is a real strategy game, and as such it is a gem, since I do not think there is another game on the market that challenges you truly at this level and in such a complex way.Why is it challenging? Well for one, you need to plan your dynasty, you need to plan your marriages to seek advantages and gains, secure the blood line, be wary of who will you end up playing next, and after that, manage your vassals, manage alliances which can only be made through marriage, manage your holdings so you can have more income and troops, manage your realm to pick laws which will either upset or make your vassals happy, or play nice to your liege if you are not independent, watch over your armies when you raise them, pick terrain carefully as it matters quite a bit, be carefull who you put in charge of your armies, watch over you flanks, be carefull what troops you use when, since the holding they come from gives them bonuses, plan your technological advancements, mind religion, convert, play the cardinal game, expand, go on crusades, plot to murder your enemies, to revoke titles, fabricate claims, and so much more.You think that list is big? Its small, even more so, get a mod from the Paradox Forums, and you can get 2-3 times more features, some mods even take you to other worlds, use maps from settings you know and love and add a ton of events and new features. The ammount of depth this game and its modding community offer is mind boggling. Crusader Kings 2 is the Skyrim of Strategy Games. Its got depth, its got versatility, its got deep modability, its a gem.And trust me, nothing compares to the feel you get, when after starting as a Count, you end up an Emperor for the first time...UPDATE: 2 years and a lot of DLCs later... This game is killing my free time still. To date the most addictive game in my life. I've never spent so much time over so many years on the same game...

												At the court of the newly founded German kingdom of Suckmahbutt:"My king, my king, we have news!""What news, you filthy peasant?""The Sarazens tremble before our great forces! Not long, and we will call Jerusalem ours once again!""Ah, good news indeed. But I have too many vassals already, don't I?""Yes, M'lord. Shall I bring you the chronicles?""Yes, nameless lowborn scum, do that. Find me a distant cousin of my dynasty whom I can declare ruler of Jerusalem once the city falls and the war is won. Can't have it to rule such a distant kingdom myself.""But there are other news, still. The Permian nobles have risen up and hold their banner for independence.""Well, what do I care? Where's Perm even supposed to be?""Why, it's a tribal duchy south of Siberia.""Why do you tell me of the rebellion then? They're too far away for me to attack them anyway.""Why would you wish to attack your own lands, my king?""MY LANDS?" The king starts laughing "How is this snowy outback tribal lectern of a duchy MY LAND?""Well, remember the cousin your grand grandfather married off to a uyghur warlord to get a treaty out of him?""No.""Me neither. But apparently their entire clan went extinct after some crazy viking coastal conquest went down and... well, I dont know the details either. But it appears you happened to inherit those lands, and now they're♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off to be ruled by a German infidel.""This is madness.""Madness? No. THIS IS... nevermind actually. But we have it 1241, and you're related to pretty much every royal in Europe, so this kind of stuff happens, I suppose.""What happens if I just ignore the rebels?""They'll win the war, you'll lose prestige and the big blue blob formerly known as France will probably take the chance to invade us.""Well, we can't have this. Make peace with the Saracens. We go to war in... what was it called?""Perm, M'lord. Will you lead the troops yourself?""No, I have to outlive my firstborn son, after all. Put him in charge, if we're lucky this lunatic imbecile glutton dies in battle and his brother inherits.""So it will happen, M'lord."10/10 would marry uyghur infidels again

content:
Posted: February 27
												This game has so many different narratives it's amazing, it's essentially a book where you're the author yet you're also the reader. What follows is a pretty epic series of events, I'm not the greatest writer but I love this story.Through much  political intrigue and disease alike, Queen Cumman of Eire (Ireland) sat on the throne. She had four children.Her eldest daughter, Muirne, married a king of Scotland who shortly after died in battle against the English. The king's brother inherited the throne and offered his hand in marriage to Muirne. Her Ambition made the choice for her. Five children later, she died in childbirth at 32. Her youngest daughter, Tuathflaith, was born Ugly and through her upbringing, became Deceitful and Gluttonous. No man desired her and so she resides in her mother's court. Through her many pleas to be married to have a family, Queen Cumman is considering one of her many courtiers for an arranged marriage. Her eldest son, Cathal, the twin of Muirne, was taught as a child by Tressach, the Marshal of Eire, a Brawny man who none could equal in tournaments. He grew up to replace his mentor as Eire's Marshal but not for long. The Queen named him as the Duke of Ulaidh, a territory of four provinces including the county of Ulaidh. Her youngest son, Aedgen, wasn't taught in hand to hand combat yet excelled his siblin on the battlefield as a  Brilliant Strategist. Through his desire for land, the Queen entitled him to the county of Ulaidh, essentially the capital of the duchy of Ulaidh. Cathal had declared independence from his mother to create the Kingdom of Ulaidh, to the Queen's surprise. Although not on his own terms, Aedgen joined him. However their relationship with their mother did not change such was their loving relationships. Years passed and King Cathal became consumed by his power. He was now known as Cathal the Tyrant. Having enough and seeking reformation, Prince Aedgen had declared a revolution against his brother. The timing was perfect as Cathal's troops were abroad in Wales attempting to expand his territory. However he had not anticipated Cathal sending a crow to the Queen of Eire who came to stop the rebellion. She had turned a blind eye to Cathal's method of reign, he was her eldest son and heir after all. Although the Queen was old she was a warrior at heart and so met Aedgen on the battlefield.  The rebellion was destroyed in an instant.King Cathal had thrown his brother in the dungeon for a few years despite his mother's pleas to release him. Eventually Cathal had offered to ransom Aedgen for 46 gold to his mother. A ransom for his brother to his own mother. She accepted immediately although not as fast as she realized King Cathal wasn't the same Cathal she had raised. Previouslly unbenknownst to her, she discovered that he had even renounced the Lord, following instead the cult of Waldensian who were heretics of the Church. Queen Cumman made a heavy decision that very same day. She declared war in the name of not only Christianity or her Kingdom, but for her own family. She had petitioned the King of Scotland (the same one, who had now married one of the Queen's kinswomen) for aid to which they accepted without question. Cathal the Tyrant's men were raised. The Queen ordered only her own men to gather, leaving her vassal's men to defend their territories. The Scottish were rallying but it would take them months to arrive. King Cathal the Tyrant marched from their capital, leading 4300 men, half of which were heavy infantry. He was accompanied by a Waldensian priest. The Queen's men of 4458 also marched. Queen Cumman decied there was only one man who, in every right, should lead her army. Prince Aedgen. Her faithful commanders, Mugron and Tressach (the very same man who mentored Cathal), secured his flanks. The two armies met on the plains in Bréifne. This clash would decide the dynasty of Eire. The battle of Ceann Lios was about to begin.SO this story is unfinished because I just had to write about this in a review. I've literally paused the same just as they're about to fight and I'm about to resolve it xD I was controlling the Queen in all of this but everything else occurred because of the game, nothing is scripted and that's what makes the game so amazing. It's a great strategy. At the time of writing, I've logged 39 hours and I bought this game four days ago D:TLDR : If you like grandy strategy and diplomacy, this game is really for you. You don't get to control anything within a battle when it commences (well you can retreat) but watching the events in the battle screen is equally as thrilling as fights in Total War.

content:
Posted: May 30, 2016
												I never played this game before. I bought it on a sale with a hole bunch of what looked like a millian DLCs and had it sitting in my library for quite some time. At some point I decided to pick it up and give it a try. Since I like playing the underdogs I decided I'd try to create a Buddhist World Empire. So I picked some random Buddhist dude on the top right corner of the map, designed a nice flag for him, browsed briefly thru the hair styles and gave him some nice sounding name. And there I was, a new Buddhist Lord in the year of 769. Boy was i confused. So damn much was going on and I didn't understand half of it. I soon found out that I had picked a guy who was the vassal of some other Buddhist lord. It took me about 30 years, but within my first character I was able to marry my lords daughter. My first character did nothing more then that, he just waited until he finally died so his son could take over. After that it was a ever so slowly progression. The more I learned how to play, the better it was. Slowly and steady I extended my new Buddhist Empire, taking over county by county, then losing half of them again to my brother the moment a transition from one leader to his son happened. Rinse and repeat. The bigger I grew, the more I understood the importance of keeping my vassals happy. I tried to adopt. A few times I had to reload because my empire had been torn apart by revolution. It took me about 200 years, until 800 something, until I felt ready to extend to the north. So I slowly took over the Tengri region above me. This worked out fine. I spend some time mixing up the bloodlines, dealing with revolts and stuff, until I finally had something of an stable empire. Now the only way to grow was to the west, into the Arabian empires. I had to reload some times and figure out the best time and approach. I seeded revolutions over there and struck just when they where hit hard by multiple regions braking into independence. This went on for a couple of years, slowly extending county for country into Muslim area. Each time I had conquered a country I did my best to convince the leader to convert to Buddhism, eventually, and very forcefully, spreading the word of the Buddha to the west. By this time I felt pretty confident that I could extend all the way to the Indian regions, where some bits and peaces of Buddhism where still existing. My dream of a big Buddhist World Empire was closer then ever. Boy was I wrong. In the year 1220 a huge army of Mongolian forces arrived and stood all of the sudden right in the power center of my empire. I was, at that time, able to round up a total of almost 11.000 men, a number I had seen increasing over the past 100 years and was incredibly proud of. The Mongols landed with something around between 50.000 and 70.000 men. I gave up fighting withing the first year. I was thrown into prison and most of my direct holdings where taken from me. My Buddhist Empire that I had been so fond of was forcefully integrated into the much larger Mongolian Empire. After some years I was demanded to change my religion to Hindu, which I did with great reluctance. Struggling to survive I tried to marry myself or one of my hires into the Mongolian Empire, but since they where Hindus alone the “Not the same caste” message killed me of. Nether the less I managed to keep my bloodline alive and seed some of them into the Mongolian Empire. I took some of my titles back and could at the very least keep my little Buddhist Kingdom, even thou the Tengri Part was lost for good, since the Khagan himself had inherited that title . I did some attempts of murder, but had no backers and mostly just ended up begin “politely” asked to drop it. I even tried to reclaim the title by force, when I saw a huge stack of 80.000 armies pass thou my land and into India, figuring I might have the time to win this war before they could reach me. I was wrong. So I ended the game as I had started it: a pitiful, meaningless nobody in some little remote state, that had given up his believe and lost every bit of his power to a greater leader.I bow before you, game. I enjoyed every single hour of this almost 60 hour game. I regret nothing. Next time I have so much more I know, I might even not fail as bad. Or even more – who knows. Next I' ll try to conquer the world with some Afrikan Empire...

												Actually, this is not a grand strategy game, but rather an RPG.When you are about eighty, when your face represents a bloody scar from cancer, when all your kids and your dear husband have deceased in the war or of sickness, even your only friend with whom you were used to play chess has passed away, and when nobody believes that you are able to last another year, but quite the contrary, they begin to reach out their paws for your titles and your collection of pictures, which you have been gathering your whole life –all of a sudden you start writing poetry, retire more and more often to your chamber lost in prayers and reading the Bible, that remained from your father to whom you owe literally everything, and then you catch your second wind, go to victorious war against nearby empire and conquer its capital, undertake a succession law reform on a surge of popular jubilation and become a true leader of the boiling, transforming society;and once during the night walk in the distant abandoned corners of your garden you face a cheeky kitten going to become your new and last friend.

number of helpful: 66 of 67 people (99%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
												This is by far the most accessible of the Grand Strategy Games that Paradox has made. A wonderfully convoluted game, where you define your goals and the means to achieve them. Be warned, you learn this game by playing it, gradually blooming into one of the most magnificent machiavellian meanies (darn you, profanity filter) the world has ever seen. Rewrite history as you see fit, Scheme and plot, command armies and then laugh at your demise at the hands of your subjects, your enemies, your supposed friends, your children and the wonderfully cruel winds of change and chance.But be warned, this game does not provide you with a goal aside from survival of your dynasty. Do you wish to unite Ireland and then subjugate the heathens that currently hold Jerusalem? How about bringing forth the downfall of the Holy Roman Empire as just a lowly Count of France? Or maybe you really just want to make that one guy pay who plotted the death of your insane, crippled and infirm Court Jester? Do what you want and suffer the consequences.All in all, this game is ripe with dark humour and seems to be easy at first. But it deceives you, sucking you in and suddenly gripping you by the balls, as you die from consumption, your son gets killed in a crusade and your remaining heir turns out to be gay, possessed and a complete lackwit, all while your allies drag you into wars and your vassals rise up in arms against you.So, laugh at the cruel twists of fate, or grow mad from the revelation. Or maybe just enjoy a quiet, uneventful life as a lowly vassal to better lords.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2015
												* Started as a random count in Ireland in the 8th century. * By 800 I had become King of Ireland. * By 1000 I had established the Empire of Britain. * By 1100 I had conquered all of France. * By 1150 I had taken control of all of Italy and crowned myself Holy Roman Emperor. * By 1160, I had launched a war on the Byzantine Empire, won, installed a Catholic on the Byzantine throne and by 1190 the Orthodox Church had been completely eradicated.* By 1200 I had inherited the Byzantine Empire after marrying its Empress, and promptly established myself as the true Roman Emperor. * By the game's end, the Irish Roman Empire controls the entirety of Western Europe and North Africa all the way up to Lithuania, Somalia and Persia, has entirely reversed the Arab conquests and seized control of Mecca and Medina (confining the Muslims to Eastern Arabia and Pakistan), and has even established several trade posts in India, effectively beginning the colonial period several hundred years early. Technology is incredibly advanced, heresies are spreading like wildfire and nobody really seems to care, so effectively the Enlightenment has begun several hundred years early as well. To top it all off, Iceland, the British Isles, most of France, most of North Africa and most of Hungary are now fully Irish.This is just one of the things you can do in this game. Just one.Do I recommend?YES.(Lag gets a bit bad in the late game, apparently because all the Greek characters are using up processing power trying to figure out who they can castrate out of all the characters in the game. Yes, you read that right - the game runs slow because the Greeks are trying to castrate the entire world. Other than that simultaneously annoying and hilarious problem, the game is great!)

												I went from a Count to a Duke, got married, had childeren, even managed to marry off my daughter to the 3rd in line to the throne and let her keep her name.Then civil war broke out over the crown between the king and his eldest son, I fought for the king and beat back the forces on all fronts except one ( The king and his army were there, so i assumed they would take care of things )But tragically the king died in battle, which left his heir and recent enemy of the crown to become rightful ruler over the lords and lands in the kingdom, concluding the war and putting me in the bad books for taking his farthers side.I decided to rebel, in hopes of being able to give my son in law and now 2nd in line to the throne the crown.The war waged on for many many years and took it's toll on everyone involved.The kingdom was split in half, the West fighting to rid the evil tyrant and the East fighting back with every thing the crown had, but it was not enough, the king's forces were pushed all the way back to the capitol.I was quick to gather more troops from the few of my vassals that were able to help.These were tough times on the kingdom, after so many years of war the kingdom's financial state was in tatters, the lords  were struggling to keep their provinces under controll while fighting off the mass hordes of troops invading their lands.But i knew the moment we had fought so hard for was close at hand.I launched a seige on the capitol with the few hundred troops i had left, the seige lasted over half a year before my forces managed to break through and begin the assault on the castle.It was a bloodshed, an absolute massacre, the king and all his men and been defeated but not before i had lost over 3/4 of my army in the attack.But the war was over, the new King had taken the throne and peace had come to the land.After all the years the kingdom spent in turmoil, only a couple of faces were familiar from the begining.most of these lords are the sons and descendants of those that rode with me against the prince before he became king.Many of their fathers fell in the war but they continued the fight for them.As the years pass following the over throwing of the old king, The lords and houses fight and conspire against one another but nothing major happens within the realm until the king, my son in law and father of my grandson, becomes ill.Shortly after he passes from his illness, many of the lords start to question my grandsons right to rule.A few small rebellions start over in the far east end of the kingdom.My son, heir to my lands and house, rides east to meet the rebels in battle.he defeats three of the rebellions before lossing the battle and his life at the fourth.With only my grandson to carry on the family name, i try my best to gather enough troops to march over the rebels and stop them from usurping the throne.All my effort is wasted tho as the young king mysteriously dies from causes unknown.I spend last years of my life fighting against the kings that come and go, only to fall victim to a event that causes me to be a paraplegic and die alone and incapable of doing anything.10/10 would feel like it was all for nothing again

content:
Posted: May 5, 2015
												One of the best games I've ever played. It looks like a historical strategy game: a large real-world map to play on, countries to control, lands to conquer, etc. But don't be fooled. It is actually a “life simulation game". You have a country (or part of it), but what you really play is a dynasty, or family. You rule, you fight, you want to see the death of your regent, you kill, you murder, you have parties, you make friends, you meditate, you do business, you love your wife, or make wild loves with your lovers, you have enemies, you are supported by your vessels, you travel around the world, you educate your children, you become the king, you are defeated on the battlefield, you lose your titles, you are nobody again, you are old, you die, you leave nothing but chaos to your sons. You go over the rises and falls of the family, interact with everyone around, and play your particular part in everyone's own story. There are tens of thousands characters in the virtually living world, everyone with his or her own life being written. Sadly you can never have sufficient energy to learn every unique story! This is one of the best games I've ever played, definitely top 5. It depicts every shining and awkward, elegant and wretched moment of a normal medieval noble guy. 12/10Those who give only 11/10, you guys are so mean.

Posted: October 24, 2014
												Endless replayability. CKII may take a while to get into, but once you learn about most, if not all game features, you'll find countless things you can do or try to achieve. Story unfolds itself, because while there is no narrative or script, your actions and actions of others really change the world and characters around your dynasty. Vast personal traits and characteristics that every single one character in game can have make up the story, as their actions are mostly defined by the personalities they have.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Quite simply one of the greatest strategy games ever made.From the outset - Crusader Kings is not for everyone. It will be best enjoyed by people who are interested in deep systems and the interplay between them. Those seeking a way to crack the "optimal" way to play, and those seeking to "win" will be disappointed, whereas those seeking emergent systems and effects will enjoy hundreds of hours of discovery. It is therein that lies CK2's greatest strength - creating a narrative through emergent systems.Crusader Kings II relies largely on the player setting their own goals and then working towards them. Be they immediate goals, medium term aspirations, or long term dreams, a large part of CK2's appeal lies in pondering how best to "exploit the code" to reach your ends. In fact, the best way to play CK2 is not to play to win, but to let the game "happen"; to let your dynasty's fortune ebb and flow with the passage of time, creating a narrative of a family streching across the centuries. Crusader Kings 2 is a game that you can sink literally hundreds of hours into and still find out new and exciting things to do. CK2 isn't a perfect game; the learning curve can be steep, particularly for those new to the genre, and the presentation is a little short of the cutting edge. But, with a fantastic level of developer support, continual free and paid content additions, hundreds of mods, and a lively, friendly and supportive community, it is fair to say that CK2 is one of the greatest strategy games of all time and, for strategy fans, possibly one of the greatest games of all time. For this writer with over 30 years of gaming behind him and hundreds of hours on the game (mostly on the Gamersgate version), it's certainly cracked the Top Ten!
