content:
Posted: June 12, 2015
												If you have the patience or a friend to teach you how this game works, it´s a game you can easily spend hundreds of hours in. If you are into strategy games I can definately recommend this one. It´s not the easiest to learn, in fact, after fifty games you will still learn more about this game, and with the continuous supply of DLC you will not get bored of this game quickly.Now, why is this game so great?+ A big map that gets expanded occasionally. You can start of as a viking king in Norway and eventually rule India, or start as a Russian Slavic pagan and become emperor of Europe. And who knows what Paradox is preparing to add next?+ A hundred of options with a thousand of choices. Whether you start off as a viking or a muslim, you will encounter similar problems. However, every religion, culture and country has it's own way of solving those. And as your character develops he will unlock (or block) other options. You'll never stop exploring these options.+ Easier and harder gameplay is possible, so whether you are new or experienced you will always find your challenge+ Great multiplayer, especially with friends. Whether you like PvPing or play versus the computer, a good multiplayer match will always keep you interested. Connecting to other players has been made easier (compared to how it was in the past), and is easily done via steam.+ Events and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold.This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.+ You can create your starting king with the ruler creater DLC+ Loads of DLC that add new and interesting things to the game. When playing multiplayer, only the DLCs owned (and activated) by the host are available. If you play with friends, have the person who hosts most often get some DLCs, so the others won't need them.+ Starting date can vary from 769 to 1337 (there currently are six bookmarks, respectively the Early Middle Ages (769), the Viking Age (867), the High Middle Ages (1066) , the Alexiad (1081) the Age of the Mongols (1241) and the Late Middle Ages (1337).+ No game will every be the same. After a hundred years into the game, you will notice considerable differences in each game. A game would not be realistic if not without flaws, so here are some of the downsides- Event and results are random. You'll never know what happens, for you could be killed by bandits during your hajj to Mecca, or you could suddenly get an extra 100 gold. This can be very frustrating, or very interesting.- Multiplayer can sometimes be unstable, especially if you play with more than 5 people. Desyncs will happen every now and then (usually you can play for an hour or two), and you have to restart your game to properly solve it. This is less common if you play with less player and if the internet connections are good. (If you have good internet, and so do your friends, this is MUCH less likely to happen.)- At first, this game might be very complicated and confusing. I recommend playing with someone with experience, if possible. - Once you get to a certain size, you will become quite unstoppable (although there are a few big armies coming to Europe, like the mongols, that might make you lose lands again). Overall I would easily recommend this game. Once you grasp how this game works, you will be able to spend hours and hours of your time into this, exploring the near unlimited amount of options, and seeing how every game is available. If you play with friends, get a co-op game going. 9/10

												Ever loved games like medieval total war but couldn't bother to do the RTS parts of the game? then this is just for you.Crusader kings 2 puts you in the role of your leader king,baron,patriarch whatever you decide to start with, unlike similar games you can't choose what you want to construct or what kind of units you want to train , but you can choose who will educate your sons, who do you want to marry , who do you want to war on via diplomacy tricks in order to expand your empire and much more including setting a plot to kill your  brother so you can become the next king and have it all ruined because of one the people who joined your conspiracy got drunk and didn't keep his mouth shut , no two runs are ever the same aside historical events.The only downside i can see in this game is how most of the factions are dlc content ,if you want to experience being the leader of the turks and declare a jihad on half the christian empire then you need a dlc otherwise you can't play them same with a lot of really fun factions like venezian merchants.

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												This game is the largest stakeholder simulator ever created. Make sure to keep your vassals and court happy to avoid revolutions or any sort of a turmoil. I have enjoyed the game so far. In particular, I liked the random events that take place throughout the game. For example, your son’s wife can get possessed by a demon and slay half of your family or your younger son will decide to assassinate you and all his older brothers to inherit the crown. Equally, sometimes you are that very person who coldly murders most of your family while being driven by hunger for power. In any scenario, you will have plenty of fun while rewriting world’s history. It feels like a game with a storylines alike Game of Thrones – intrigues, assassinations, betrayals, seduction and other joys of life.I would personally advise to play this game on Ironman mode only, as it forces you to embrace all the chaos you have caused and all challenges that have emerged in the game, forging your mind to be more strategic next time and also not trust anyone.

Posted: October 31, 2014
												I have 500 + hours on Crusader kings 2 and it is probably one of mmy favorite games, let me give you an example of just how awesome this game can be. When i first got the game i decided i would play in ireland at the 867 start date.  i would eventually conquer all of ireland and scotland and wales. my king was king Eric V he was a badass as he had conquered wales for the glorius Irish empire. however his second son was lustful of the throne, his name was Bob (no joke) since i had the law that only the firstborn son of the ruler would succed, Bob killed his elder brother Aethulwulf and inherited the throne for himself, but thier was a crucial flaw in his plan. Aethulwulfs son Eric still lived, and the game let me play as Eric not bob. so i spent my entire reign as duke of connacht ploting to take back the throne that was rightfully mine. in the year 1024 me and my sons decided taht it was time to take my birthright. i demanded the throne but was rejected by uncle Bob and i started a civil war that would last 20 years. the irish and scottish lords on my side and the other lrish and welsh lords on bobs side. needless to say that war killed off 13 family members including Erics second and fourth son. by the end Eric had killed Bob and all his children, but was maimed. he died a year after taking the throne from his wound. i would later port this game into EU4 and conquer the world. when i was about to port my game to EU4 i looked at the history of my family, and Bobs name in history was "Bob the bad" 100/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game. To date, I haven't played another strategy game like it, and it's likely there aren't any. This game can make somewhat similar games, like Civilization, feel quite disappointing.This game is all about your family, politics, your characters, your religion, your culture... there's a lot of depth. And after you've played for a few hours, you should have a story worth telling to someone. Stories that alter history. It easily beats out almost every other strategy game I've played in this way.This is one of the few games where it's okay to kill your wife, your brothers, and your uncle's 2-year-old child, all for the sole purpose of aspiring to be even greater than they were.Be warned, this game can be very frustrating: You learn more through your failure than your success, and sometimes there's something big you've overlooked for the last day (or month) you've been playing. I highly recommend you try the demo and watch some people play this game online (Youtube, for example) before you're determined to buy it.It also has some of the best modifications out there for any strategy game, including a Game of Thrones mod that's well acclaimed and probably the best Game of Thrones game out there. As a sandboxy medieval European story simulator, this game shines. You will giggle at the death of little boys and marrying their sisters as you inherit land and claims for war. Very rarely do I feel like I waste my time with this game. There's no grinding. And Paradox tries to improve it with patch after patch, which is nice.The only downside, in my opinion, is the way the DLC is released, with song packs, skin packs, etc. however, the higher priced DLC is worth buying for the most part - just read what it's about before you buy it and you should be good to go.This is, by far, the best game Paradox has to offer, and one of the most worthy games on Steam to buy.

												Ridiculously good game from a great developer. Deep, Immersive, Intelligent, and the only game that truly has a Game of Thrones mod that fits. A breath of fresh air with a unique perspective. If your an adult gamer this is an absolute must buy. If you are an intelligent teenager you may like this as well. Anyone younger should not apply, THANKFULLY. Paradox has always been great about making wonderful games that are art and art is not a democracy. Thankfully, this game is not made to cross platform appeal to everyone from 5 years old to grandmas. Long live Paradox, my favorite game developer.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Great, unique game that any grand strategy enthusiast should purchase.Crusader Kings II fills an excellent niche of strategy where the goal is to control and survive internal struggles as it is to survive the machinations of your neighbors.  A full-blown character development and dynasty system gives incredible richness to the world and the player's attachment to character, family, and kingdom.This is fantastic game for single or co-op play.  It takes a long time to learn and master, but once you've got it the game becomes very fun and satisfying.My primary complaints lie in the underdeveloped economic side, underdeveloped religious system (especially for non-Catholics and non-Norse) slow casus-belli capture-one-county-at-a-time conquering system, and multiplayer instability.Note: The developers have consistently released new content for the game, which is incredible.  A lot of the key additions are also given for free for vanilla users.  That said, there are some DLC expansions that add important new systems or create additional depth to existing ones, which therefore should be purchased with vanilla.  If on a tight budget, I would definitely pick up Old Gods.  All other DLC at your discretion.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful6 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 24, 2015
												This game will hate you. It will leap up and slap you in the face. And as a result, you will never want to leave its side. As a wise man once said: Life has no Ctrl 'Z'.A great many things are beyond your control, unusual in a strategy game but far more true to reality. Perhaps you will pause in your travels at a tavern, nurse a cool ale, and the tavern will explode, killing you instantly. Son of a... Is nothing sacred?Or maybe your favourite son will take over as regent when you grow old and decrepit, only to steal all your titles and imprison you. Bet you're regreting your refusal to aid your brother in killing the little sod now, aren't you?Perhaps you become just another in a long line to die from Medieval Europe's most dangerous plague - 'Suspicious circumstances'?It's never entirely clear how suspicious they are, or what you're supposed to do about it, but you know what they say - Life's a female dog. Or maybe, at the ripe old age of 84 you'll die from syphillis. Irritating it might be, but you'll be unable to fight the surge of pride that you were still getting it on at an age when most men's fading eyesight ensures they can't even see the appropriate body parts any more.And the list goes on: vassals tearing your Empires apart, mobs killing your tax collectors, rioting zealots, crusades, becoming blinded, castrated, imprisoned, diseased, incapable, having your son born the anti-christ, or, god forbid, losing your favourite hunting hound (why, why, oh cruel, wretched world?). CK2 will punish you, and you will love every second of it, because when you do manage to pull everything together, nothing in life will bring you more joy. Not since Firefly has anything been more deserving of the tagline 'Someone ever tries to kill you, you try to kill 'em right back.'

content:
Posted: November 25, 2014
												Crusader kings 2 is a really fun game. It might look intimidating at first because of all the things you need to think about (especially if you take a big character for your first game). But the basic are pretty easy to learn. Playing this felt like an episode of GoT.This game has almost unlimited replay capacity and gives you a great sense of satisfaction when you defeat and conquerer enemy territory. Another plus is that now, the game has official servers so its much easier to play with friends. As for the DLCs, i'd say they're worth it (excepts for the one with the Aztec invading Europe, that makes absolutly no sense whatsoever). My favorite 2 are the old gods (you get to play as vikings) and the ruler designer (create your own dynasty).I've had my fair share of hours of play and i can say, if you're into history, you're going to like this game (hell if you're not you might start to like it now)

number of helpful: 5 of 7 people (71%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2014
												This is indeed grand strategy. And it is excellent.Multiple aspects of this game elevate it to its status at the pinnacle of its genre. First of all, the deciding factor for me that makes it better than other Paradox games is the added RPG element. No longer are you simply commanding a country and desperately trying to stop inflation. Now you also feverishly work to impregnate your barren wife and secure an heir while assasinating your cousins left and right. If that doesn't sound like fun I don't know what does.There's also the great open-ended freedom of this game. Unlike Civ, which is simply a race to dominate, Crusader Kings allows you to do whatever the heck you want. Feel like taking on the Golden Horde as King Kazimierz of Poland? Give it a shot. Or just chill as Earl Murchard in Ireland where literally nothing happens.Did I mention that there's a 32 person multiplayer mode?TL;DR- You should totally get this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2016
												Two years ago, I got CKII on special offer just for the hell of it, and I played it for about 4 hours. Now, I've logged about 800(Make that 900) hours on it. Well, When I played it for 4 hours...I hated it. it was just so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ complicated, boring, I couldn't work out the systems, it was BORING. I only played it when I got bored, until one day, in september 2014, I was playing it out of boredom and I married someone. Her father died shortly after, and she inherited his duchy in norway. Then, my character died and his 15 year old son became head of one of the most powerfu, duchies in Norway. fast forward 100 years and We're kings of norway and england. fast forward 50 years anf we're counts of some rocks in Cornwall. then, we became kings in less than 25 years. And that's the magic of CKII. anything can happen. It's impossible to describe, do I'll split it into pros and cons.Cons: a learning curve of 90 degrees and an absolutely disgusting tutorial system that teaches nothingPros: when you learn the game, It becomes a vibrant, sprawling mass of politics, marriage, religion and warfare, trying to get on top and stay there while everyone else tries to kill you, and desperately surviving. The game tells a story of events, families, murders and warfare. Oh, and incest... It's gritty and down to earth, showing the reality of medieval history in the ways history class never could, whilst giving a delightful account of the bedroom antics of rednecks and showing that one kid, one wife who likes guys a bit too much, one bad trait, one guy with that ♥♥♥♥ing trusting trait can completely screw up a plan that has been in progress for 100 years, only for you to turn events around and become king of Spain, when you actually meant to be king of Scotland.In short, this game can be tlked about endlessly, but only understood and loved when it's bought, when you climb that pile of corpses that mainly consist of your brothers because ypu havent got Primogeniture succession/ Climbing the learning curve and play it. It's been my favourite game for the last two years and has won that title easily due to it's ability to be remarkably simple, yet so ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ complex, you're always learning.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
												Eh. Crusader Kings 2 is embletic of Paradox's greatest virtues and flaws. On the one hand you have a truly immersive game worth hundreds if not thousands of hours of gameplay, but at the same time any attachement to the game itself erodes as they go for breadth instead of depth. In an year in the lifespan of one of their games, you can be sure that as much as six months will be unplayable for one reason or another due to the cycle of DLC - > Bugs -> Patch -> Bugs -> Patch - DLC that leave the base game a complete mess for new players and forces you to take on the whole of the DLC to get an actual cohesive experience. For me it's kind of telling that the most solid previous generation game they had was Victoria 2 which ceased recieving DLC a long time ago but was still a lot of fun and almost never had any bugs at end of focus period. When you add into that Paradox's tendency to decide how you can or can't play your game (closing off North Korea mode, multiple "fixes" to player-chosen game-styles and not allowed achievements in single-player), then it becomes a very love-hate relationship with a largely well-meanign company slightly too reliant on DLC to keep their franchises going. I'd give CK2 a thumbs up purely for appreciation for the hours of quality gameplay provided but given how burned out it's left me on Paradox as a whole I find myself unable to do that.

number of helpful: 27 of 50 people (54%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 17, 2015
												Really not my sort of game, despite me trying my darndest to enjoy it, for I have friends who love it. Thirty hours in and it still only makes limited sense to me (and no, I'm not a complete and utter idiot). Far too much seems dependent on luck, for a start. Event pop-ups occur where you can make some rather limited decisions, and there will be cases of 'fourty-percent chance something you don't want happens, sixty-percent something you do want happens'. Quite a lot of cases of that, in fact. If that makes for enjoyable gameplay for some people, then have at it - I'm not stopping you. For me on the other hand, constantly saving so that I can reload if I get buggered over by RNG isn't what I'd consider to be fun (or I guess you could play ironman mode and let fate take its toll, though I rather play the slots at a casino than this all day, for they offer about the same level of entertainment and cost the same, what with this game's ludicrous amounts of DLC).Most of the game seems to consist of waiting. Wait for your piety and prestige stats, both of which are doing some very subtle things you probably won't realise at first due to the tutorial mode failing to teach you much of anything. You can speed things up, but then I suppose it's just a case of waiting for the things you want to happen but faster. Apparently there's strategy involved, but if you can make sense of it you're doing better than I did. Infantry units get combat bonuses when standing on certain terrain for example, but good luck telling what sort of terrain you're on as it's pretty damned hidden away - I only figured out how to tell about twenty-five hours in. If you do realise what's going on, good luck telling if that bonus is ACTUALLY having an effect and isn't bugged, like a lot of things in Crusader Kings 2 seemingly are.Then there's the fact you have no actual goal to achieve presented to you. Some people love that, apparently, take Minecraft's success for example (though even Mojang decided to add an 'end boss' to their game). I personally just sit there and wonder "why did I pay for something that's telling me to make my own fun?". If you have any hobbies, I'd go do those instead. You could say that you should aspire to take over the world - well, okay, but is it actually enjoyable? Only if you're a particular sort of person, it seems, as I'd be bored to death by the time I manage it; most of the game involves nothing but waiting. The game just isn't fun - I tried the multiplayer, and when it wasn't "desyncing" (which was a CONSTANT issue, desyncing being tantamount to a crash as you had to exit and restart the game when it happened to someone) for half the game I was tabbed out and talking to people on Skype, as the only convenient way to play multiplayer is on the slowest setting - after all, having people pause when they need to is impractical - and thus the only 'gameplay' I was experiencing was, yet again, waiting for stuff to happen.I'd like to try and deconstruct the individual mechanics of the game from my limited understanding of them, but really, there's no point. If you're not already playing Paradox's "grand strategy" (a genre I'm pretty certain they alone make games for) games, chances are you won't enjoy this. I'll end this on something objectively bad about the game - its DLCs, or more aptly put its micro-transactions. Multiple, tiny and worthless 'infantry packs' for soldier units you barely pay attention to and multiple 'portrait packs' for the already rather poorly rendered ruler images. Then there's the DLCs that actually add gameplay content - supposedly, they come with free patches that add content even without you purchasing the DLC when they're released. That sounds great and all, but then you hear that those patches have a tendency to come with a host of game breaking bugs and it apparently takes Paradox forever to fix anything. Great. Though I haven't actually purchased any of the DLCs, I have experienced them via my multiplayer escapades, and they seem extremely limited - essentially, think if you modded Super Mario Bros, for example, so that you're running around as Peach instead of Mario. That to me is what the DLCs appear to amount to, what with them consisting of apparently exciting new features like "new start dates" and new rulers to play as, or then you have the Way of Life DLC, where you pay for about five-hundred words or so packaged into event pop-ups that are just more of the same RNG nonsense as before. I suppose that's all great if you already enjoy the concept, but where the game's appeal originates from I cannot even fathom. I never felt like I was applying much strategy (though I suppose you do with extreme patience), I was never having much fun, and I think my friends enjoy the game more than they would otherwise because of their apparent interest in history (which this game pretends to have a lot of, that being historically accurate gameplay, which is also a complete lie as you'll never truly play the lives of infamous rulers, the game simply isn't even nearly sophisticated enough to achieve such an experience). If you want to learn history, great - but read a book, don't play this game.

												TL;DR: Time-intesive game+ Fragile save files = Recipe for disaster.Very frustrating.The game is fun enough, but runs on the concept that you invest a lot of time into one particular playthrough.Thats fine, especially if you like the sense of achievement it brings when you do finally rule the world starting from a humble tribal lord in the middle of nowhere. number of helpful: 16 of 29 people (55%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 12
												Crusader Kings II is a vast pretty map with an enormous database of historical figures and all their relations, titles and whatnot, that plays out as a giant real time spreadsheet. I've enjoyed many abstract games with minimal graphics (Dominions, Conquest of Elysium, Tales of Maj'eyal etc), each with large inventories of foes, items, locations and so on. But I cannot say that I even began to enjoy Crusader Kings II.The learning curve is vertical, with tiny icons studding nearly every window. While there are tool tips to go with each view, because of the number of little buttons and icons, I had a difficult time figuring what each section of the tutorial window went with what controls. Even when I did digest what a tool tip might mean, I still had little idea what the described control did in the larger game.About six minutes in, I was asked by the tutorial to pick an ambition for my King. Since he was single and there was already an alert about only having my brother (who doesn't like me one bit) as my sole heir, taking care of that seemed like the natural first order of business.Forty-five minutes later I'd clicked on everything that I could find that had anything to do with anyone in the game getting married. Not only could I not marry my ruler to anyone, I had absolutely no idea WHY! While I noticed some contextual tooltips that listed out qualifiations required for a particular action, most of which were dense and had obtuse names, I couldn't find a anything that would tell me why my young King could marry no one.The kicker for me was the tutorial telling me that my choice of getting my King married was a wise and sensible first ambition. There even came a tutorial window directing me back to the marriage window that I'd already discovered on my own and could (as near as I could tell) in no way afffect.I could have perused the manual or searched for guides online, but spending nearly an hour on one step of a tutorial and getting nowhere made me feel decidedly unwelcome.I'm sure there is a deep, rich game under all the very specific terminology, the family trees, under the byzantine UI screens and between the insane number of tiny buttons and icons, just waiting for someone wonky enough to sort it out. Normally, I feel like I'm that wonky person; not so with Crusader Kings II.I found the game entirely unapproachable, so I've given it the thumbs down. I have no doubt that there are the patient few who have cracked the UI and are conversant in all the very specific terms for medieval succession and the associated ranks and whatnot. But if you're not willing to learn a whole set of antique jargon and navigate screens studded with damnable tiny buttons, and abstracted into meaninglessness icons, you're like me and this game isn't for you.

content:
Posted: January 10, 2013
												Great game, even though a bit clunky and outdated, but the recent changes in Paradox developement policy make me strongly question whether any potential buyer should actually support this.Crusader Kings II is a highly-complex (to the degree where it easily becomes overwhelming to new players and can, literally cause a game over in less then one minute of play time) Grande Strategy, in which you take control of a dynasty of medieval rulers, trying to lead your family to power and glory.You can expand via forging claims or creating new titles, followed by your armies marching across the land. Or wed your sons and daughters to create alliance that may or may not last decades, or may even have your grandson on the neighbouring kingdoms throne, in time. Or you skip that 'in time' part and just go and murder everyone else who might lay claim to the throne to put said grandson there. Or, just murder that one too and inherit the throne yourself.Jep, this sounds a bit brutish, but that's the way Feudalism works. And after all it's not a onesided story... watch for ambitious sons, or you might find that your wine tastes a bit funny.In the end, CKII is an oustanding game for anyone interested in a mix of medieval dynastys, light RPG and deep Strategy. But be warned that the game is hard, unfair, sometimes utterly random and difficult to get into.As well, be advised that the Multiplayer mode is painfully unstable. With a lot of patience (and reloads) it's possible, but usually a better choice to play Singleplayer.However, this actually great game is sadly overshadowed by the publisher behind it.Paradox started out as a niche game producer with a lot of effort and heart. But across the years they have more and more developed into a mainstream game industrialist and more and more often it feels like they prefer to storm their supporter's wallets instead of hearts.Low-quality, bugged, patches are common among multiple games (most mentionable CKII and EUIV), the dev's behavior in the forum is... erratic and unprofessional at times and on top of that Paradox has started to build a history of dropping the support for games even whilst promised pre-purchase packet content wasn't ever delivered (namely, War of the Vikings).Result: 7.5/10 A bit clunky and without reasonable Multiplayer, but still a solid game.But still, avoid  purchasing this or any other Paradox title. Vote with your purses and hope they redeem their ways.

number of helpful: 22 of 41 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2015
												If you've ever played Civilization and thought it would be great if the whole game were the middle ages and I actually got to oppress the peasants, then you will enjoy this game. Similarly, if your family reunions make you wish you could speed up time and exert exacting control over who everyone in your family marries, this game will really blow your hair back. And finally, if you like playing The Sims but wish you could invade your neighbor and burn their ugly house down, well, I count myself fortunate to not be your vassal.The gameplay really nails a humorous historical blend of strategy, simulation and role playing. The user interface is packed with information that can draw you in for hours, once you master the very steep learning cliff. The graphics are fairly minimal, but honestly just right for the game.Unfortunately, so many of the extras that you wish you had control over are fairly pricey DLC, for what they get you. Want to tell your uppity heir to shave his stupid moustache? $4.99. Tired of everyone looking the same, wearing the same 5 outfits or having historically inaccurate ethnicities? $1.99, $0.99 and more for each part of the globe.They have expanded the game several times, and the features continue to be added even if you don't by the expansion. From this standpoint, you can get many hours of new gaming experience out of it.However this makes for an unpredictable experience. I bought the game to enjoy multiplayer with my wife. While the added features are great, the stability of the game has its ups and downs. Recently, the Mac version of the game has been very difficult to enjoy. Crashes to desktop and out-of-sync errors become more and more common as our conquests abound and demense expands. Any more, we can't reliably go for more than hour without one of us suffering a setback and having to fully reload the game.Another common problem is that the game will protest that we have different versions when setting up the multiplayer server. This requires us to fully reload the game again.I love the game and wish I could play it more. I'm not opposed to paid or free expansions and feature additions, but given the choice between a rock solid, unchanging game and a buggy, evolving game, I'll choose the former every time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												Crusader Kings II doesn't have any plot or main story to go trough. Instead you have only one objective. Make sure your family never falls and try to make your dynasty as prosperous as possible.This might sound boring at first but in reality it´s extremely addictive. There are many ways to try and climb the ladder. While sometimes brute force is enough, often you need to be way more devious. While marrying your son to someones daughter might seem harmless at first, it gets way more profitable once her brothers have mysteriously fallen. Having good relations is always important unless you want to be cornered against multiple armies or just find your main charracter being stabbed to death leaving your young child on the throne unable to deal with the matters at hand. As changes can happen very quickly, Crusader Kings II makes you put in your A game or otherwise you will be swept back into nothing or to total extinction. While the suprises can be depressing at times, coping with these problesm is what makes the game so addictive. Prosperous moves aren't always the wise ones. Marry your daugher to the neighboring kingdom to fight your enemies and yes you won. Too bad they decided to invade you during the next generation as they had a rightfull claim to your throne. Expand carefully and make sure you will win both now and in the future.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												Played as a Germanic Frisia and raided the shorelines of England. After the king the great died and left the kingdom to his 14 year old son I decided to take the seduction focus and I made the Christian mother to the king a lover. I then decided to burn England again, sacrifice the mother to the Allfather and leave the kingdom filled with B A S T A R D S, my B A S T A R D S.Crusader Kings 2 is by my opinion the best game from Paradox. If you really love to play games that makes you think or you love conquering land then there is no better choice than this.What makes this game so good?: The fact that you take your own choices that will effect the future so much. You can start as the Holy Romans and form Prussia, or you can lose all and have to play as a small kingdom far east. The basic game is simulated to act the historical events, but you can change them and make your own history.This strategic simulator will conquer more of your time than it will of Europe.There are problems of course, handling your vassals, defending your kingdom and keeping your dynasty alive. But the worst thing is that you have to buy expansion moduels to play as other charakters or different religions. So buy the expansions, but only when it is sale on them.If you are still holding back from buying it, then ask yourself. Do I love independence, difficulties and history?

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Takes a really good game to make me play for 16 hours almost non-stop on my first session.Crusader Kings 2 is an RTS like many of Paradox's previous titles; highly complex (where your typical RTS is concerned) and providing a highly realistic simulation of empire-expansion. Every facet, save tactical involvement in battles, is explored with detail, and with much at the player's control.One of the key features in CK2 is it's dynastic political system. Not only must you secure your line of succession through heirs to continue in your quest for glory, but there are no formal alliances. Everyone you can count on is either directly in your sphere of influence and thus obligated to serve, or aligned through familial ties.Even though I bought it during the sale, as previously I was unsure, now that I've played Crusader Kings 2, I can definitely say I'd not have issue with paying full price for it. This is even one of the few games I wouldn't be opposed to paying full price for DLC.5/5

content:
Posted: March 2, 2015
												Put it this way, I've played plenty of games where you can beat your enemies into submission, but never one where you can shag their sisters afterwards. Politics, Intrigue, War, Diplomacy, everything. This game has it all. No tactics to speak of but that only adds to the depth in its own way. On a different game you might say, "hmm, his army is twice the size of mine, but hey, I can probably beat him, I'm a good general'. On this game, you are more likely to think, 'If I go up against him I'm going to get my♥♥♥♥♥♥handed to me on a plate. I'd better stay on his good side until I'm strong enough.' This is a great strength of the game, and you have to set long term aims and goals if you want to win. For example, at the start of my most successful game, which was as Duke Ethelred of Wessex on the Old Gods campaign, I ruled a small Duchy in the South of England, with a massive Norse army making its way south to burn and kill everything. Through a hefty bit of luck involving several strategic alliances, I was able to secure control of England. By putting a woman on the throne of West Francia, who my heir then married, I was able to begin a process of conquering all of France. When the crusading era arrived, holy wars brought me muslim spain and the Holy Land. In 1140, The House of Wessex now rules as Emperors of Britannia, the masters of Western Europe and the Levant. It won't be enormous military might alone that brings you success, you need to utilise every ounce of political acumen you posses, taking advantage of every opportunity that comes your way, praying that you don't make the wrong choice. "My Lord, the Duke of so-and-so is rallying your vassals against you". "Oh I'll be fine, I've never been more popular." Next thing you know, ten thousand men are kicking down your door. In my view, the perfect strategy game.11/10

I love this game and I'd recommend this game to whoever asks me if it's worth buying. Beware though, it's a fairly deep rabbit hole. 9/10

content:
Posted: July 23, 2013
												The most accessible of Paradox's flagship 'Grand Strategy Titles' may as well be it's best. Crusader Kings 2 is a Dynastic simulator set in a turbulent medieval Europe. The player takes control of a character and is tasked with creating a dynasty that will endure the test of time, political intrigue and backstabbing family members. Not unlike other Paradox GS games, the systems are quiet hard to grasp but in due course, one begins to appreciate the complexities and the possibilities they entail. My personal GOTY for the year 2012 and favorite medieval mass murder simulator. Play it!Latest Update 2016:Game's changed so much since launch. Still spectacular though.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												I've played this for hundreds of hours (hard to believe, actually) and nearly all that has been spent in the Game of Thrones mod. I don't have huge interest in the period and have little knowledge of the various houses and dynasties. And, in CK2, that's where the interest is. You're not taking England, France, Spain, etc, somewhere by the end of the game, you're taking a dynasty. And that might not be very far. You might get imprisoned and die in jail, then must carry on as your infant son, who dies before reaching adulthood - game over (actually happened to me). Or you might reach the end of the game, having ups and downs, and only have 1-2 provinces more than you started with. The game is focused on characters and their relationships and all your greatest plans can come to nothing because an important person dies. And often people will die, or lose traits/abilities, randomly. You could die naturally in your 40's. Die of depression. Lead your armies in every battle and lose the 'brave' trait. Be a superior fighter and lose a duel to someone who can't fight (AGOT mod). And all seemingly, based on invisible random dice rolls. This can be incredibly frustrating, given how important characters are. It's something, if you're invested enough, you can fix with console commands and save edits. Or you can just grit and bear it. For me, I wasn't invested enough in medieval Europe to do so but I am in Westeros. But it's frustrating work that shouldn't be necessary.If you like the setting, or a setting provided by a mod, enough to live through the games frustrating randomness, there is great enjoyment in trying to build your dyntasty and watch the lives of your kin, your friends and your enemies, playout. If only Paradox could come up with a way (maybe in CK3) to tie your fate less to chance and more to your actions and those of the AI.

"My Lord, the Duke of so-and-so is rallying your vassals against you". "Oh I'll be fine, I've never been more popular." Next thing you know, ten thousand men are kicking down your door. In my view, the perfect strategy game.11/10

content:
Posted: June 19, 2013
												Simply put this game is awesome.Why don't I recommend it? Because it could be better.If you are going to buy this buy it with all expansions.trust me you won't regret it.When paradox promises endless replayablity they deliver.One thing the game excels in is giving you a feeling of achievement.In most non-paradox games when you end a playing session you amy have built a base or have gained the best weapon but in essence you haven't really done anything.the weapon or base make it too easy.Once you reach your goal you are done.However with CK2 thats not the case,you may have become emperor of the HRE but that doensn't mean that yor game is over,your son could just as easily loose the title as you gained it.And even when you are done with the game theres always the conversion to EU 4/3 to carry on the journey.The graphics are good and the music is very fitting.Still if you've never played grand strategy I suggest you try the demo.Just be aware the demo is not the finished product so you should use it only to judge the core game and not the nitty gritty details of teh game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												A wonderful game of grand strategy and choices, CK 2 is all about guiding your family dynasty to greatness during the Mideveal period of history.  There are so many decisions to be made that can affect your family, A marriage could lead to an alliance, or it could lead to a rival making a claim on your for your crown. What to do with prisoners and traitors? You can execute, banishment, release, take away titles, each choice you make effects how your vassels view you and could increase your hold on your kingdom, or breed rebellion among your people.  Should you go on a hunt, have a feast, blot out the infidels or sponser a fair to gain favor with the peasants, every choice you make can bring reward or potential ruin to your dynasty.  The only drawback in this game is warfare is a bit simplistic. I do enjoy having to have a real reason to go to war, not just because I can. This title definitly has taken ahold of alot of my free time. I also enjoy that the developer is actively supporting their product and are constantly patching and upgrading the game and mechanics along with providing new DLC content at the same time.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 20, 2013
												Best kind of surprise package by Paradox Development Studio. A game which gives you the challenge of trying to keep your dynasty alive and in power whilst also tempting you with expansion and wealth. Take part in holy crusades to re-take holy catholic lands and earn prestige through wars. If war's not your game, use cunning and intrigue with strategic marriages and spies to help fabricate claims on land, call in allies and take the land without lifing a finger.If you get the DLC's you can play as the muslims in the east, become a caliphate and declare jihads and watch as your fellow believers sweep accross Europe in the name of Allah. Bring the Byzantine Empire their previous glory and reform the Roman Empire, gaining justifications on all her previous holdings.Watch in a twist of history as the Aztecs land on European shores bringing with them new and strange diseases. Watch as they cut down kingdoms and forge their own empire.Play as a Republic, forgeing a dynasty of wealth and power through trade, then use this new wealth and power to cut out your own empire. (Like the Romans did!)And soon you will be allowed to play as Pagans, like the vikings and plunder gold and wreak havoc in the name of Odin. Each Pagan will have its own unique taste.You can even create your own Dynasty and play as yourself and your family.I've got to say, the care they put into this game makes it 100% worth every (now extinct Canadian)penny I paid. Not to mention how open the game is to modding. There are mods that completely change the game. Play the Game of Thrones or Elder Scrolls! There are actually mods that allow it! Not to mention all the other mods out there, it's great.It's a must buy even if you don't like games like this, it might change your mind.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Do you enjoy killing family members? Do you like to ruthlessly kill your neighbor's sons in hopes of obtaining his land? Have you ever wanted to have the Norse religion spread all across Europe? If you said "Yes" to any one of these questions, Crusader Kings II is for you! Now you can commit crimes against humanity, sleep with your brothers wife and cause the destruction of everything those pesky Catholics ever knew and loved. All without any real world risks! Please note: Yelling "Finally I killed my son and inherited England" may cause family and friends to become concerned about your mental stability and moral and ethical well being.(As an additional serious note: This game is decently challenging to get into and even harder to master, but has an excellent simulation of life in Europe during the medival period, has wonderful story-telling potential and will teach you a thing or two about European medieval history without you even noticing. Crusader Kings II will make you cry, laugh and learn all with only a map, some faces and a cart full of fun and interesting choicesIf you like history and strategy games, you will love Crusader Kings II.)

Even recommended it to professors as a sort of simulation of the time period.12/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 17, 2013
												This is the ultimate medieval dynasty simulator. You rule over realms in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East and India and have many different cultures and all christian faiths at your disposal and yes, you can change both during the game.You play one character at a time, a person with skills, virtues and flaws which has inherited titles, prestige, money and also claims on titles from his parents. You can wage war, but only when you have a proper (medieval) reason to do so.Holy War, assassination plots, cheating on your spouse and inheritance of land just through succession will be part of your daily routine if you play this game. You can work your way up from a low Count title to becoming an Emperor, become a heretic, annihilate cultures and religions and make your dynasty the most powerful one in the world of CKII, dominating the world from Portugal to India and from Norway to Ethiopia for centuries.The expansions allow you to try different religions (Norse Pagans, Muslims, Buddhists, Jews...), different governmental systems (Eastern Rome, Trade Republics...) or expand the gameplay in other directions (deeper focus on roleplaying or certain religions, earlier start dates etc).Buy this game. But be warned, it's about characters, not about optimizing economy or developing technology. Another warning: It will eat up your time...

I was wary because Paradox's last title, while historically brilliant, had a bit too high a ratio of menus and info to meaningful decisions. This game on the other hand is not only a fantastic representation of the period but also perhaps the best alternative history engine ever created. If you like management games with omnipresent failure conditions (Tropico, for example) and you're okay with making up your own goals or playing for the sake of seeing what happens, then you have to get this.

content:
Posted: March 1, 2016
												There's very little to say that the dedicated, vocal and truly helpful CK2 community has not already said.  Grand Strategy is the name of the genre, but everyone knows the game is really both a broad and deep Medieval Dynasty Simulator.The learning curve is often described as steep, but it is only as steep as you want it to be.  Want proficiency in all the subsystems so you can build a dominant hegemonic empire?   Just want to fool around with history and see what happens?    The game will happily take all comers.If new to the game, don't worry about the DLC avalanche.   Try out the base game and see if it's your cup of tea.  (Hint:  if you like history or strategy or power or maps or even sweeping dynastic stories, it will be your cup of tea.  If you like all of these things, then welcome home.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2013
												A brilliant game, which models accurately and immersively all of the political intrigues and dynamics of the era. The game, however, is rather lackluster if played completely bare of mods- it requires several of the main expansions to really become one of the best. Part of this is the fact that certain gameplay styles and religions are locked from being playable until you purchase DLC which can cost upwards of ten dollars.The game, beyond it's diplomatic and intrigue features, is actually rather bare. Combat is incredibly simplistic, and often numbers will win a battle regardless of the skill or quality of the opposition's troops. The economy must be taken at face value- the different types of settlements provide nothing but a choice between high tax and low levies or vice versa. Churches are something you will probably never build outside of roleplay, as your player character cannot use them (theocracies are locked from being playable) and they provide both medocre taxes and levies.Some mechanics still need tweaking, often successions between dynasties and rapid succession between characters is a little too seamless, as the strength of one's claim after a title has been usurped is irrelevant, as is the legitimacy of one's dynasty- if there is no eligible heir within the dynasty, the title will succeed to the character with the strongest claim in the game, and if that is not an option, it goes to the most powerful vassal in the realm. Often this will happen with little disruption to the operation of the realm, even whilst wars are being waged. History demonstrates that there would be significant upheaval if 5 kings succeeded to the throne within the space of a month. In the game, however, this is not the case.All in all, however, these things can be overlooked, in favour of acknowledging the massive amount of effort that has been put into the game to make it immersive, easy to learn and fun to play. It is quite accessible, however there is still much to learn if you wish to master the game of thrones.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Hours played is conservative because I generally play offline. I like to try out a lot of different games and genres, but I always come back to CK2 (and I lose entire weekends to it when I'm supposed to be working). My favourite strategy game by far.It wasn't easy for me to learn (to be honest, I'm still absolutely terrible at it) - I had to look up things online frequently at the beginning - but even screwing everything up can be fun. I love the dynastic aspect of it (think Rome TW's dynasties but better). I get a kick out of marrying people off and stealing heirs. I don't often play an aggressive game - you can war and pillage if you feel like it, but you don't have to, which makes the game ridiculously replayable for me because eventually I get bored of raising armies and chasing idiots across the sea.My favourite part is earning kingdoms through a couple of generations of sneaky, well-placed betrothals. Which always inevitably backfires. You start doting on your little bloodline, get cocky because the wives start popping out geniuses all day erry day, and then bam, your only son gets landed by inheriting some obscure dead relative's puny county, marries an inbred forty year old, and screws up all of the beautiful perfection. I fangirl this game so hard...The game is frequently updated, and for me, stability is rarely an issue. I love the DLCs (yes, even Conclave). I want more events, and traitors, and faces... as I said, fangirl. But I've played this so much, and I still find new stuff in every playthrough. Well worth the steep learning curve.

												Probably the most deep and engaging historical game ever made.  Turns you into a know-it-all of early European/Eurasian history...and interstingly enough was probably was the best supplemental material for my History major throughout my college career lolBut seriously, CKII is like the real-life Game of Thrones.  You act as a sort of sociopathic line of kings/dukes/counts/etc and try to navigate the incredibly complex political realm of 800-1300 CE.  The game taught me more about the pagan faiths and general world geography than any class ever did.  Insane amount of detail and historical information, including political figures and their personal traits.  Makes you appreciate the game even more.  Even recommended it to professors as a sort of simulation of the time period.12/10

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												Crusader Kings in an incredibly indepth sandbox medieval grand strategy game. Simply put you are given a map and a dynasty and your task is to do what ever you want with them! Take a lowly Count and raise him (or his heirs) to Emperor. Eliminate your rivals at court through intrigue. Conquer Europe and Asia in the name of a restored Empire! You choose an objective to achieve and use the games carefully designed features to achieve it.Things to note: There is no real time battles; numbers, terrain and generals dictate win/losses.It's not a graphically interesting game; don't expect the spectacle of the Total War series here.It can be tough to get into; initially the game can be overwhelming but if you stick with it you won't be disappointed.In my opinion this game is a must have for any strategy fan; push through the learning phases and you will loose hundreds of hours to this game.More info in the video bellow for those interested.[url=https://youtu.be/QHbOkqzLrCc/url}

content:
Posted: March 9, 2016
												This is a pretty nice game to be honest, although, really, I enjoy it a lot more since I got a fair amount of the DLC.Been on and off this for some time, but the more I play it, the more I love it. It's not like the Total War series (which I originally thought it would be like) at all, it's so much more gritty and, in some ways, devilish. It gets to the point where you manage to get past the learning curve which, thankfully, isn't too steep, and you're able to build a nice kingdom that has secure borders and is the ire of many. Pretty soon you'll have people bowing to you and wishing your might didn't come crashing down on you!The intrigue system is, for all intents and purposes, your home at some point or another. You'll be using this to stage either Grand Feasts or Mass Conversion to a religion or culture, but it's more fun after a point to be the WRONG religion in relation to your neighbours. Makes things  very  interesting. There is a little bit of micro-managing, especially when it comes to trying to get claims and manipulating other powers, but once you get this down, you'll be living in a spinster's paradise.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 5, 2014
												No doubt that this is a great game.Crusader Kings II can hook you in on a historic strategy gameplay. There are tons of possibilities of fame and shame on this game. Essentialy you play as a dynasty, whether your dynasty be the line of kings and emperors, or be just vassals, that is your choice. Though you start small as a lowly vassals, it is possible for you to become emperors, and it's also possible to be "demoted" to dukes at the same time.This game have quite deep (and quite correct) simulation of kingdom life. You have to have a heir to continue your dynasty, keep your vassals weak, keep your liege happy, and so on. You can't wage war on every kingdom, you have to have a valid cause of war for that. To gain that cause war, you have to work hard. You can send your steward to create some fake claim, or you can start a holy war, or you can combine assasination and marriage so you can press your claims, etc.There are so many mechanics in this game. The problem is that this game's help and tutorials are next to useless in explaining this or that to you. But on the other hand, the tooltips are really handy. You can know why this vassal is mad, or why that vassal is happy. Nearly all components in this game can be explained by the tooltips, though the mechanics is still hard to learn.In the end, this game should be bought. For me, it's 9.25/10, slightly beaten by EU IV.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
												A wonderful game of grand strategy and choices, CK 2 is all about guiding your family dynasty to greatness during the Mideveal period of history.  There are so many decisions to be made that can affect your family, A marriage could lead to an alliance, or it could lead to a rival making a claim on your for your crown. What to do with prisoners and traitors? You can execute, banishment, release, take away titles, each choice you make effects how your vassels view you and could increase your hold on your kingdom, or breed rebellion among your people.  Should you go on a hunt, have a feast, blot out the infidels or sponser a fair to gain favor with the peasants, every choice you make can bring reward or potential ruin to your dynasty.  The only drawback in this game is warfare is a bit simplistic. I do enjoy having to have a real reason to go to war, not just because I can. This title definitly has taken ahold of alot of my free time. I also enjoy that the developer is actively supporting their product and are constantly patching and upgrading the game and mechanics along with providing new DLC content at the same time.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
												Do you enjoy killing family members? Do you like to ruthlessly kill your neighbor's sons in hopes of obtaining his land? Have you ever wanted to have the Norse religion spread all across Europe? If you said "Yes" to any one of these questions, Crusader Kings II is for you! Now you can commit crimes against humanity, sleep with your brothers wife and cause the destruction of everything those pesky Catholics ever knew and loved. All without any real world risks! Please note: Yelling "Finally I killed my son and inherited England" may cause family and friends to become concerned about your mental stability and moral and ethical well being.(As an additional serious note: This game is decently challenging to get into and even harder to master, but has an excellent simulation of life in Europe during the medival period, has wonderful story-telling potential and will teach you a thing or two about European medieval history without you even noticing. Crusader Kings II will make you cry, laugh and learn all with only a map, some faces and a cart full of fun and interesting choicesIf you like history and strategy games, you will love Crusader Kings II.)

I was wary because Paradox's last title, while historically brilliant, had a bit too high a ratio of menus and info to meaningful decisions. This game on the other hand is not only a fantastic representation of the period but also perhaps the best alternative history engine ever created. If you like management games with omnipresent failure conditions (Tropico, for example) and you're okay with making up your own goals or playing for the sake of seeing what happens, then you have to get this.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 14, 2015
												This game is quite possibly the easiest and most addicting of the Paradox grand strategy titles to get into.Audio - The base audio that comes with this game really captures the mood of the time, with additional themed soundtracks you can purchase for a small sum. Even the effects really add to the game with relevant sounds notifying you of births, tithes collected, war declarations, etc.Environment - You put yourself into the role of a ruler ranging from the 8th - 15th century AD with a map ranging from the Indian subcontinent to Iceland, Ghana to the Steppes of Asia. Though this range is smaller than with other Paradox titles, with unique mechanics like the tribal system, the Indian caste system, and such there is a great feeling of variation depending on where you start in the map.Replay Value - With thousands of characters to choose from (or you can choose to make your own), tens of religions, cultures, and various ruling styles the replayability in this game is endless.Shill factor - The list of DLC that comes with this game is daunting, however most of it is cosmetic. The refreshing thing with Crusader Kings 2 is that with each large patch (such as the one which introduced India) all players will benefit from free content regardless of whether they want to dole out more dosh for DLC.It's a fun game, especially if you enjoy a bit of roleplay. Go buy it and ♥♥♥♥ around as a duke, well worth the cost.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												Crusader Kings 2, or CK2 for short, the game that introduced me to grand strategy games as a genre and Paradox games in general. For me the best feature of the game (this might be seen as a combination of different features of the game) is that it focuses on characters. By this I mean that I take the role of a character and my decisions influence me and others around me. The game plays a lot like a more traditional RPG (BioWare games comes to mind). While spending to much time deciding who I should marry, or if I should go hunting or just attempt to seduce my lieges wife you come to realize that this game also has some very interesting strategy elements to it. Managing your levies and planning the expantion of your realm is something that you can spend a lot of time on. The best part is that you don't really have to do anything unless you want to. If I don't want to go to war over a neighboring county I don't have to! The game can be played the way you want. I can go on and on about all the things you can do in CK2 but I will close this review by saying that CK2 is a wodnerfull game. The RPG elements is what makes me coming back time and time again. Some ending remakrs:- The game can be very overwelming in the begining. I still don't grasp all the systems in this game and the best thing is that I don't really have to. Take your time, watch some tutorials or use the in game scenarios to slowly learn the game, it is worth it.- Hover over most things to get more information, just something that might help early on and can help you learn the game a bit faster.- Have fun! Play the way you want to play. Don't be afraid of testing things out, you can always load the game if you want to or live with the qonsequneses.Hope you enjoy!

Posted: June 19, 2013
												Simply put this game is awesome.Why don't I recommend it? Because it could be better.If you are going to buy this buy it with all expansions.trust me you won't regret it.When paradox promises endless replayablity they deliver.One thing the game excels in is giving you a feeling of achievement.In most non-paradox games when you end a playing session you amy have built a base or have gained the best weapon but in essence you haven't really done anything.the weapon or base make it too easy.Once you reach your goal you are done.However with CK2 thats not the case,you may have become emperor of the HRE but that doensn't mean that yor game is over,your son could just as easily loose the title as you gained it.And even when you are done with the game theres always the conversion to EU 4/3 to carry on the journey.The graphics are good and the music is very fitting.Still if you've never played grand strategy I suggest you try the demo.Just be aware the demo is not the finished product so you should use it only to judge the core game and not the nitty gritty details of teh game.

												Over the years I've logged over 1250 hours in this game. To say that it is one of my favorites would be an obvious given. What i like the most about it is that it focuses on the lives of a dynasty that I can create and develop over the annals of medieval European history. With all of the expansions this can also be extended to the mid east and Indian subcontenant.  The game continues to evolve with each successive addition to add more and more variety between governing types, religions, cultures, and even lifestyles. I would not call it high action, though it has its moments, but a game that can be paced and simply enjoyed in terms of strategy. If you love strategy and the intrigue of dynasty building this game is for you.As a bonus; if you're a fan of game of thrones.. the game of thrones mod is amazing.

												I picked this game up on free weekend "Can't be that hard," I said, "Being king is easy!" I said. I loaded up the tutorial, and all was going well. I had fought back agaisnt a rebellious vassel, had a proper heir and everything. That's when it all started. My own brother had asked the pope to declare me a demon or whatnot, something like that. Anyway, I had begun an assassination plot agaisnt him, and I tried to convince my nephew, his own son to join me in his assassination. He refused and went crying to his father, "UNCLE LOOFA IS TRYING TO KILL YOU, PAPA!" I soon declared war on the poor guys, before my vassel had rebelled agaisnt me because it turns out his daughter was married to my brother. He was soon publically executed, until all the kingdoms due south of mine were apparently all besties with my vassel, and oh dear, turns out they murdered my heir before the ragequit.Deus vult.Edit:While king of Leon, the black death swept over europe. Now, I, the king, didn't think I'd have to worry. I had to worry. First, my wife was infected. Then my children. Then me. What did I do? I offered to some muslim emirates down south to have my youngest son. Of course they'd accept, they'd want a hostage to keep control over me.Oh, how they were wrong.While they where considering the offer, I myself contracted the plague. That was fine, though. Even in death, my plans would work. As Pedro was shipped away to the south, a jihad was declared. Soldiers poured into Leon, but then Pedro arrived.Soldiers were taking and razing the land as they moved towards the capital, but in a coughing, painful fit of laughter, king Alfonso died in his throne, knowing that in the big picture, he had won.Pedro, you served Leon well. Thank you.

content:
Posted: September 1, 2016
Crusader Kings II takes place between 1066 and 1453, and there are literally hundreds of characters throughout that span that you can play as. Being a king is very different than playing a count, but neither’s journey is less interesting. The stories play out constantly, whether you play a provincial count or a godlike emperor. While your goal is ostensibly to sustain your dynasty as long as possible, Crusader Kings II is more about the journey than the goal. Getting there is more than half the fun.Crusader Kings II is complex, and the tutorials explain perhaps a third of the stuff you’ll really want to know. After a week of play you still have burning questions about major game systems that just aren’t covered in the tooltips or manual. But the potential is totally there, so long as you can stick with it and conquer the sometimes-overwhelming interface. There are little buttons everywhere, and while the interface is pretty useable once you get used to it, it’s never as easy to find specific characters or visualize their relationships as it probably should be. This in particular makes the game feel impenetrable at first.Overall Crusader Kings II can be a heck of a lot of fun. The more you understand, the more fun you have. Once you start getting past the learning curve you’ll find yourself more and more absorbed by all the complex little dramas that swirl around your nobles.THE GOOD- Challenging gameplay- Strategic interpersonal relationships- A complex and deeply rewarding system of diplomacy- Many DLC's for expanded play- Well-designed and easily navigable menusTHE BAD- Steep learning curve- Complex game mechanics- Overwhelming interface- Many DLC's are needed for optimal playDISASTER | BAD | MEDIOCRE | OKAY | GOOD | GREAT | AMAZING | MASTERPIECE

content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
 Crusader Kings II Review This is going to be a long in-depth review into Crusader Kings 2 so you better get some snacks to fill yourself up for the read.  Gameplay (8/10):  Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game in the category of gameplay. It gets this uniqueness by bringing 2 genres together in a way different then usual. These two genres are RPG and real-time strategy. Unlike a game like Age of Wonders III where your RPG elements come from designing a undying hero, Crusader Kings II lets you create and play as characters that range from weak to powerful yet no matter what are extremely mortal. In Crusader Kings II your character has a set of traits that they start with however this can change in a blink of an eye. These traits can be obtained and loss through events and the traits can alter certain events meaning if you truly want you can play as if you have those traits. Crusader King II also brings in RPG to a slightly bigger level with not only managing relations with the outside world but with realistic an historic vassals who can leave powerless if left unattended. Also Crusader Kings II makes you manage your vast and growing dynasty in the game who can press their own inherited claims. In the category of strategy Paradox brings their classical style of strategy to this game with you playing and altering the past from historic time marks from between 769-1453 which then you may convert the save file so you may continue the saga on another Paradox strategy game. In the end where this game lacks is due to the massive locked content behind DLC (more covered later). Certain religions and start dates are completely inaccessible because of this.  Mechanics (9/10):  One area where Crusader Kings II excels in is mechanics. Unlike its counter-part in Europa Universalis IV, Crusader Kings II has a great variety of things to do even during peace time. Crusader King II has an in depth relationship system where certain decisions you make and traits you have can have an effect on a relationship with someone. These effects are shown as numbers where +100 is the highest opinion you can get while -100 is the lowest opinion you can get. Crusader Kings II is a game where relationships can turn from sweet to sour with the help of another system, the intrigue system. The intrigue system can be used to plot and kill people of your choice however if caught can drastically change the situation.  The systems work well and fit in together like a perfectly planned puzzle, even the marriage system. Using the marriage and intrigue systems in unison you can make your wife claim all of her brother's land and then she can pass it on to your heirs. There is three major systems that I haven't talked about that form the basis of this game. The first one includes a hierarchical feudal system. Firstly there are counts (the weakest playable characters) who own pieces of land who have barons living in them. If you have a few counties you may become a duke and etc. all the way from kings to emperors. The base mechanic is that you may only have vassals (people with land under you who pay taxes to you) that have a lower rank. You have a max amount of vassals you can have before you begin suffering from penalties, this is to stop rapid expansion and is to balance the game. Another base system is the holding system. Every character has a set amount of counties or baronies they can hold (a.k.a holdings). Duchy, kingdom and empire tier titles do not count as a holding. In a matter of fact having multiple of one of these titles can boost your holding limit. The final major system is the casus belli system. Unlike a game like Civilization V you need a casus belli to go to war (i.e. it is a reason to go to war). You may get these by fabricating claims or by naturally inheriting claims and more. There are so many more mechanics but then this review would become miles long but overall mechanics are detailed and in-depth, the only problem can be the huge number and complexity of them.  AI (7/10):   Like most strategy games Crusader Kings II has a difficulty option that changes the way the AI works. However it is unconventionally placed in the options menu. Yes this allows you to change the difficulty of a save mid-way through however it changes the difficulty of all the saves. Looking at the actual difficulties the differences between easy and hard can be seen. In easy the AI plays more passively and only declare war for casus belli they already have and rarely ever fabricate their own claims. In hard this is different as the AI will take a few more risks and is more likely to jump on someone's weakness even if it is a small one. Also they more pro-actively fabricate claims on other people's territory and in harder modes the AI is much better at vassal and family management. However there are smaller aspects of AI that is useful yet terribly flawed. If you have excess holdings you are able to let a AI give out your excess holdings. This piece of the AI is broken as it can give out the duchy your capital is in and make one of your vassal massively over-powered. In my opinion the gap between easy and hard is too great and a finer scale of difficulty must be used. In addition to that the easy AI should be given some more intellect so very basic decisions do not come out with the most outrageous decisions that even a new player would not make.  Price (6/10):   This is often the deciding factor when buying a game and that is the price. The base version of the game is £25.99. In my opinion this is a fair price but this is where the drawbacks come in. This game has huge amounts of DLC that when bought and added have great changes to the game and bring in a lot of new features and a lot of these features were developed after the game came out. However this is not the thing with all the DLC. When choosing a character you choose a person out of the map but some of these characters (e.g. Muslims) you cannot play in the base game. The game goes furthermore to rub it in your face by discolouring the play button, deactivating it and by saying "You need to buy the Sword of Islam DLC". That is not the only problem. Some of this DLC seems pointless. Although a lot of these pointless DLCs are 99p, these are things you would expect to be part of updates. For example new music, new textures for cultural units and even more useless crap. Yes people may say "it is a business they need to earn money" but do they really need to go this far? I think not. To get all the content of this game it costs a staggering £122.99 (This number is not outdated). This is by far the biggest dragging point of the game.  Overall (8/10):   Overall this game is very unique in its content. Despite its slight complicity once you’re into the game it just becomes second nature. It’s one more turn equivalent of just that one more kill or just that one more plot to finish effect does leave a massive effect on you. Oh and not to forget it huge replay-ability where no two runs are the same. I believe that the overall good quality of the game can somewhat make up for the high price.

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												Takes a really good game to make me play for 16 hours almost non-stop on my first session.Crusader Kings 2 is an RTS like many of Paradox's previous titles; highly complex (where your typical RTS is concerned) and providing a highly realistic simulation of empire-expansion. Every facet, save tactical involvement in battles, is explored with detail, and with much at the player's control.One of the key features in CK2 is it's dynastic political system. Not only must you secure your line of succession through heirs to continue in your quest for glory, but there are no formal alliances. Everyone you can count on is either directly in your sphere of influence and thus obligated to serve, or aligned through familial ties.Even though I bought it during the sale, as previously I was unsure, now that I've played Crusader Kings 2, I can definitely say I'd not have issue with paying full price for it. This is even one of the few games I wouldn't be opposed to paying full price for DLC.5/5

Posted: June 26, 2015
												Let me start of by stating that Paradox Studios is by far my favorite company. They make their games mod friendly, they create games with great depth and amazing mechanics that essentially develop into hours and hours spent constantly replaying as different characters in different eras of time. Not only do they release the game with this much customer care, but they also continuously update it and include features without DLC that dramatically improve the game. Crusader Kings II is a ridiculously fun strategy game that you'll be able to spend hours and hours playing, while never boring in the process. It's character development and focus on historical realism makes Crusader Kings II quite possibly the best video game ever made. New comers to strategy will find it really hard to understand the mechanics at play, as it took several people that I know (as well as myself) HOURS of gameplay to finally get a clue as to what we were doing, But, once you understand the game, you begin your reign over the medieval world.

You should have the major DLCs like The Old Gods, Charlemagne, The Republic, Sons of Abraham, and Legacy of Rome.I'll admit that initially this game appears to be an overwhelming database of content, but the truth is that it only looks that way and is in no way confusing once you get about five hours into it. There are too many features for me to mention, but I HIGHLY recommend buying this game as it has tons of replay value.Update: ~800 hours in and the game still is just as fun. I can't recommend it more!
