content:
Posted: February 5, 2015
 Crusader Kings II Review This is going to be a long in-depth review into Crusader Kings 2 so you better get some snacks to fill yourself up for the read.  Gameplay (8/10):  Crusader Kings 2 is a very unique game in the category of gameplay. It gets this uniqueness by bringing 2 genres together in a way different then usual. These two genres are RPG and real-time strategy. Unlike a game like Age of Wonders III where your RPG elements come from designing a undying hero, Crusader Kings II lets you create and play as characters that range from weak to powerful yet no matter what are extremely mortal. In Crusader Kings II your character has a set of traits that they start with however this can change in a blink of an eye. These traits can be obtained and loss through events and the traits can alter certain events meaning if you truly want you can play as if you have those traits. Crusader King II also brings in RPG to a slightly bigger level with not only managing relations with the outside world but with realistic an historic vassals who can leave powerless if left unattended. Also Crusader Kings II makes you manage your vast and growing dynasty in the game who can press their own inherited claims. In the category of strategy Paradox brings their classical style of strategy to this game with you playing and altering the past from historic time marks from between 769-1453 which then you may convert the save file so you may continue the saga on another Paradox strategy game. In the end where this game lacks is due to the massive locked content behind DLC (more covered later). Certain religions and start dates are completely inaccessible because of this.  Mechanics (9/10):  One area where Crusader Kings II excels in is mechanics. Unlike its counter-part in Europa Universalis IV, Crusader Kings II has a great variety of things to do even during peace time. Crusader King II has an in depth relationship system where certain decisions you make and traits you have can have an effect on a relationship with someone. These effects are shown as numbers where +100 is the highest opinion you can get while -100 is the lowest opinion you can get. Crusader Kings II is a game where relationships can turn from sweet to sour with the help of another system, the intrigue system. The intrigue system can be used to plot and kill people of your choice however if caught can drastically change the situation.  The systems work well and fit in together like a perfectly planned puzzle, even the marriage system. Using the marriage and intrigue systems in unison you can make your wife claim all of her brother's land and then she can pass it on to your heirs. There is three major systems that I haven't talked about that form the basis of this game. The first one includes a hierarchical feudal system. Firstly there are counts (the weakest playable characters) who own pieces of land who have barons living in them. If you have a few counties you may become a duke and etc. all the way from kings to emperors. The base mechanic is that you may only have vassals (people with land under you who pay taxes to you) that have a lower rank. You have a max amount of vassals you can have before you begin suffering from penalties, this is to stop rapid expansion and is to balance the game. Another base system is the holding system. Every character has a set amount of counties or baronies they can hold (a.k.a holdings). Duchy, kingdom and empire tier titles do not count as a holding. In a matter of fact having multiple of one of these titles can boost your holding limit. The final major system is the casus belli system. Unlike a game like Civilization V you need a casus belli to go to war (i.e. it is a reason to go to war). You may get these by fabricating claims or by naturally inheriting claims and more. There are so many more mechanics but then this review would become miles long but overall mechanics are detailed and in-depth, the only problem can be the huge number and complexity of them.  AI (7/10):   Like most strategy games Crusader Kings II has a difficulty option that changes the way the AI works. However it is unconventionally placed in the options menu. Yes this allows you to change the difficulty of a save mid-way through however it changes the difficulty of all the saves. Looking at the actual difficulties the differences between easy and hard can be seen. In easy the AI plays more passively and only declare war for casus belli they already have and rarely ever fabricate their own claims. In hard this is different as the AI will take a few more risks and is more likely to jump on someone's weakness even if it is a small one. Also they more pro-actively fabricate claims on other people's territory and in harder modes the AI is much better at vassal and family management. However there are smaller aspects of AI that is useful yet terribly flawed. If you have excess holdings you are able to let a AI give out your excess holdings. This piece of the AI is broken as it can give out the duchy your capital is in and make one of your vassal massively over-powered. In my opinion the gap between easy and hard is too great and a finer scale of difficulty must be used. In addition to that the easy AI should be given some more intellect so very basic decisions do not come out with the most outrageous decisions that even a new player would not make.  Price (6/10):   This is often the deciding factor when buying a game and that is the price. The base version of the game is £25.99. In my opinion this is a fair price but this is where the drawbacks come in. This game has huge amounts of DLC that when bought and added have great changes to the game and bring in a lot of new features and a lot of these features were developed after the game came out. However this is not the thing with all the DLC. When choosing a character you choose a person out of the map but some of these characters (e.g. Muslims) you cannot play in the base game. The game goes furthermore to rub it in your face by discolouring the play button, deactivating it and by saying "You need to buy the Sword of Islam DLC". That is not the only problem. Some of this DLC seems pointless. Although a lot of these pointless DLCs are 99p, these are things you would expect to be part of updates. For example new music, new textures for cultural units and even more useless crap. Yes people may say "it is a business they need to earn money" but do they really need to go this far? I think not. To get all the content of this game it costs a staggering £122.99 (This number is not outdated). This is by far the biggest dragging point of the game.  Overall (8/10):   Overall this game is very unique in its content. Despite its slight complicity once you’re into the game it just becomes second nature. It’s one more turn equivalent of just that one more kill or just that one more plot to finish effect does leave a massive effect on you. Oh and not to forget it huge replay-ability where no two runs are the same. I believe that the overall good quality of the game can somewhat make up for the high price.

content:
Posted: March 1
												CK2 is awesome. Mainly because it depicts lots of characters in great detail. Your game will be not just conquering territory it will be roleplaying as ruler who must establish relations with his vassals. You must rely on them and not let them become too powerful, or they would overthrow you. Dying by hand of assassin is real possibility for Feudal Europe (or Middle East which is also part of the game), so is dying by plague or other illness. And then you will go on playing as heir to your character, which leads us to another important and fun part of the game - dynasty making, which if played well could give you new lands without war and claims for new titles (casus belli is extremely important in European politics, you can't just declare unjust wars right and left).Disadvantages:1) bugs, mainly due to rich mechanics of the game that was changed in game development. There are many bugs, but you won't encounter more than few. The reason is gameplay is different for Muslim Caliph, French King and Mongol Khan, most bugs affect only specific rulers under specific conditions.2) Game slows down all the time. It is especially annoying on slow PCs. You start game on old laptop and it is quite ok for first century, but then your game is 10 times slower and you just have to quit playing.3) Tactical battles are too primitive. It is not Total War, nothing spectacular.Summary: worth playing is you like medieval history or like strategy games.Advice: wait for sale. -75% happens. And buy with all DLCs as.package.

TL;DRThis game makes Jaime and Cersei's p0rn shoot at Joffrey's funeral seem like rainbows and unicorns. ___________________________________ 26 year old king: Involved my sweet uncle by granting him a title and some hot, sinister honey to a plot to assassinate the nurturing breasts that fed me from my youth--my own mother. Imprisoned my sweet sister unsuccessfully. Now she is determined to tear her flesh and blood apart. Betrothed to an eight year old who had the specialty of being humble, a plus in my book! Everybody did it back then when this was considered to be the norm, at least for the British monarch, but now I finally got a taste of virtually grasping its essence in its most truest form. Alas, once I quit the game because I was getting very sleepy did the sudden realization of what morbid behavior I had done begin to gnaw deep within my grief, drenched soul. Taylor Swift's Shake It Off! always soothes me at day's end. Swift's angelic voice and mesmerizing twerking won't even relieve this guilt trip of mine. What have I become? WHAT. HAVE. EYYEEE. BECOME! ...the only logical solution is to start a new game to redeem myself. I feel better now.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 17
												Crusader Kings II is one of those hit-or-miss games. It will miss with 95% of the population. Hell... you probably only have this game because of a deal, received it for free, or purchased it in a bundle. Amongst strategy lovers, 75% of you guys will consider it a miss. But... for those of you who are as stubborn as myself, this game will suck you right in. Before we continue any further... I have attempted to play Crusader Kings II almost 5 times before I actually enjoyed it. I quit 5 times out of frustration and simply not getting this game. If you love strategy, you must keep trying. Once I did understand the complex mechanics, I fell in love... just not with my first wife Matilda that I may or may not have simply used for an alliance with the Duke of Flanders. If you're reading this... sorry dear...My highest recommendation for beginners, start off at the bookmarked game and play as William the Conquerer. If he still holds the title, William the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, you're a little behind. Move up a few months. Playing as William the Conqueror definitely helped my learning. And once you get a feel, you'll want to play as one of the Kings of Spain. Poor King Sancho dies, leaving his kingdom divided amongst his 3 sons. They are respectively the Kings of Galicia, Leon, and Castile. Will you be the youngest King of Galicia, who struggles with his Portugese Duke who plots to overthrow him? Or the middle King of Leon, the plotter with high intrigue that holds the support of his two sisters and his mother in his realm... Or perhaps the brave King of Castile who has under him the legendary El Cid, the greatest military mind of his time. Now, let's backtrack for a moment... Crusader Kings II has an in-sane amount of roleplaying involved. There are even fantasy elements that are added with some DLCs that come about, some of which let you fall in love with a horse, seduce your sister, eat your vassal, sacrifice virgins to God, or blind and castrate your own father. If that's not good enough, create your own character and dynasty and destroy history as we know it. Now here's a little example of something I normally do in a normal gameplay. Almost all my playthroughs, I hated the Holy Roman Empire. Solution? They give the pope a million reasons to hate them. Get enough money, piety, prestige, and the pope can grant you an invasion right. Net the right alliances, and you can storm into claim the Holy Roman Empire for your own. But suddenly expanding so massively will only get me overthrown... so why did I bother taking it? Simple. I destroy the title and grant everyone independence and watch all hell break loose in a nation that's magically divided into 100 country-states. Now, that being said, Crusader Kings touches base with a variety of religions, cultures, different ethnicities, and government. There are many playstyles and no one way to go about winning. You may become the Emperor of a grand Empire, such as the Holy Roman Empire, or be a starting Count that aspires to become a Duke or even overthrow the King... If those don't work, become a Republic state and work on building your house and fleet to make money as the more notable factions of Venice or Milan. With so many elements to this game, you may expand your influences and become Emperor through some basic means of marriage, alliances, marrying off your children and siblings, fabricating claims and fighting for claims. You can grow your power through military might and expand one county at a time. You may also save up and focus on wealth, expanding your land toward finances and heavy taxes, and putting that hard-earned gold to good use... and by good use... obviously we mean to kidnapping, assassinations of enemies, buying the pope's love, buying your liege's affection, heck, buying everyone's affection so that they may support you and elect you to becoming the new ruler. Oh... right... did I mention you could also just do the kidnapping, assassinations, and various other ploys yourself, start factions against your lord, and simply screw up anyone at your leisure? And if that isn't your thing... be pious and be with the Pope, and he will surely grant you invasion rights, which then may be called to action through alliances and simply declaring war. If that doesn't tickle your fancy, you could be the master of diplomacy, and let the people who love and support you do the plotting for you. As a ruler, you will come across many random events that determine the path your kingdom and your character goes. As a summary, Crusader Kings II is a must-play for strategy lovers, history lovers, roleplay lovers, and peoplewhosecretlylovedoingevilthings-lovers. You and I both know that you will all end up either castrating your own brother or sacrificing virgins somewhere along the line... Crusader Kings II is the gateway to heaven and hell with immense replay value, amazing roleplaying elements, and most important of all... sleeping with your brother's wife and letting your brother raise your ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ child.Did I mention you get to name your kids and any land you own...?Yours TrulyThe Emperor of PonylandDynasty of Rainbows and Magic

Posted: August 30, 2016
												Probably the best game I've played in a long, long, time.In my opinion, it's more choice & consequence focused RPG than strategy game. At least, that's how I've been playing for twenty hours, thus far. I've had so much fun as my randy Transylvanian duke, with a penchant for seducing every woman at court, and the wives of others - sadly, he later died in his bed due to a mysterious snake being in there with him; haters gonna hate, I suppose.I had hoped you could play as a religious order, or an unlanded noble - that would make for even more awesome roleplaying - unfortunately you can't. I highly recommend this, with some of the major DLC - especially ones which add even more character interaction, choices, mechanics, etc. I'm currently playing as a merchant prince of Venice, and it really is a very different experience - I feel like some sort of mob boss.My only complaint is the battle system. It's often just a frustration - which is why I was glad I didn't have to focus on it as a merchant prince of Venice.(P.S. I only fell in love with this game when I stopped playing it as a pure strategy game, and played it for the immersive character interactions. Haven't been able to stop playing it since.)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2015
												Crusader Kings 2 is important for a number of reasons. It's one of those games that you can only get on PC due to the sheer amount of depth to it. When you start the game it is very confusing and very baffling, so I’ll start off with why you should play it and then how to get into it.If you played Total War and you hated the empire management element but loved the battles then this game probably isn’t for you. What Crusader Kings 2 provides you with is essentially a toolbox for managing your Dynasty. But what is a Dynasty right? Well you play as an independent country or a duchy in the middle ages and when your character dies you play as their heir, and keep on playing until you have no heirs left. Which can happen if you manage to♥♥♥♥♥♥off the whole of Europe.What this leaves you with is a game that is based almost entirely on intrigue and plotting. You marry not out of love, but to forge strong alliances so that you can call them into war. You can assassinate people who don’t like you and try and manipulate situations so that you end up in power. In my first play through my daughter killed my son to solidify herself as heir, I then discovered the plot and had her executed. My brother than hated me for killing my daughter and had me killed. Then I went on playing the game as my brother – who everyone actually liked because he got rid of a terrible king. He then ruled for a ridiculous period (50 or so years), united Ireland and had a ton of children with 3 different wives. Once he died, all of the children started plotting against each other to get themselves into power. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s.It sounds great on paper right? But mechanically it’s quite complicated because there are SO MANY moving pieces to consider. This is the how part of the review. When you start, you want to do as many tutorials as you have the patience to sit through, and then do a learning scenario like playing as the King of Leon. Once you’ve done that a few times, then I strongly recommend picking a kingdom on Ireland and having your short-term goal being the Unification of the Kingdom of Eire. There are a few really comprehensive guides and wikis on this game, so do have a look at those as well.It’s a treat to play this game once you get into it. Just don’t come in expecting a Total War game. What this is, is essentially dynasty simulation at its finest. So fine that there’s a really awesome Game of Thrones mod for once you’ve got to grips with the game! Oh, and be wary of those Mongols in the 13th Century. Those guys are♥♥♥♥♥♥♥

content:
Posted: July 21, 2014
												I urge everyone who purchases this game to not throw in the towel after a mere couple of gaming hours. With over 11,000 buttons to click, terms to remember and legalities to learn, it is definitely more complex than your average hack-and-slash, but an extremely rewarding experience when you stick with it. I would most likely compare this game to chess, especially its tutorial. When my grandfather taught me chess, he showed me all the cute little figurines, showed which way they could move and kept winning for seven years, until I finally mastered the game enough to beat him. This is exactly how I feel like with CKII. I played through the tutorial, read several different guides and have an extremely helpful friend with over a 1000 hours of this game under his belt - and I still very vaguely grasp what I'm doing. My daughter is the wife of the Kaiser - good stuff - but is it - but who should I kill... That's what a fraction of a second of the game feels like. All of this is emphasized by the fact that you literally don't know what you are supposed to do  - you choose it, there are no built-in goals. In conclusion, this game has an extensive learning curve. It takes time to master, but is very rewarding once you do. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2012
												Let me tell you some actual things that I've done in that Crusader Kings II:I was the Queen of Wales, and I saw that the person who was third in line for the duchy of York was an unmarried woman. She had three young children, two boys and a girl. The current Duke of York was a young man, with a single son, and a chaste wife. I invited the woman who might inherit York to my court, and I arranged for her to marry into my family. Meanwhile, I betrothed all of her children to members of my family. Being a member of my court, she had little choice in the matter. Then, I murdered the Duke of York, sending assassins after him. It took a small fortune, but he was eliminated. His young son made a poor feudal lord, being four, and it was quite easy to convince his court to murder him. With that murder, my erstwhile courtier became the Duchess of York. Two generations later, thanks to my long term family planning, the Duchy of York came into the possession of my family.I was a Scottish Duke, and I served my king loyally for two decades. He was my friend, my cousin, and I served with pride as his chancellor. But he sickened and died, and his young child became king. A wee lad of six, and I was made his regent and tutor. I also discovered that I was his heir. So, I murdered him, and usurped the crown. My new vassals were unhappy with my actions, so I purged them and replaced them with cousins. I betrothed my son to a brilliant, lustful Byzantine princess, and all seemed well. Until my son swore an oath of celibacy. With needs her husband could not fulfil, my daughter in law turned to me. Not so long after, a baby boy was born. I legitimized the child, murdered my son and my wife, and started over with my new family. I was known as Malcolm the Good.I was the Empress of Cymru (once known as Britannia), and my realm had turned to the Cathar faith. The Cathar faith is a Catholic heresy that believed in reincarnation, that a person might be man or woman in any given life, and which believed in gender equality. Being Cathar, I was able to land a woman with a fine mind for tactics as a countess, and I made her my marshal. When the Caliph declared a Jihad against me, trying to retake Hispania, I gave her command of my armies. At times, all three flanks of my main force were commanded by women. That countess led my armies in every major battle, becoming pregnant twice during the course of the war despite being 39/40 at the time of the births. She was wounded more than once, she led armies into battle while being outnumbered 3:2 or worse, but she never lost a battle. She became the second most famous person in all of Europe at that time, with more prestige than the Pope or Caliph or Byzantine Emperor or the Khans. By all accounts, over three hundred thousand infidels were killed by her forces. After the war, she suffered from depression, she lost her courage, but she was still the best person to lead the fight in a Great Holy War against the Norse tribes, far from her home in Portugal. She died at home, and one of her born-on-a-battlefield sons succeeded her.I was the head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark, and a treacherous family member gathered an army and struck directly at my capital. He destroyed my retinue army, and assaulted my capital. Outnumbered, with no support from my allies, with my other family members choosing to support the usurper, I was forced to surrender. I remained a duchess, but all of the barons and mayors and religious holdings in my territory reported to the usurper. For a decade, I raided Ireland and northern France, carrying off loot and hostages for ransom. Building myself a great hoard, I waited until the right moment. Eventually, the usurper became embroiled in a war in East Francia, fighting most of the still powerful Karling family. With his armies weakened, I hired mercenaries and I struck at his capital, assaulting it and all of his holdings. He tried to bring back his armies, but my own force outnumbered his almost four to one, and he was crushed. He died in battle, and I imprisoned his brother and heir; I banished him from my realm, reclaiming my rightful titles as head of the Norse faith and Queen of Denmark.I have conquered Europe in Odin's name. I have forced the wives of my defeated foes to become my concubines, and I have shed oceans of blood in the name of women's rights. I have accidentally married my great-granddaughter and deliberately married my sister. I have served Popes and I have murdered Popes. I have been trained in the art of war by a Ronin. I have had misadventures involving a merry band of outlaws in my forests. I have restored the Roman Empire. I have murdered spouses for fun and profit. I have seen battlefields where the dead number in the tens of thousands, and fought wars where neither side could muster five hundred men. I have turned back the Mongol hordes, and I have watched in despair as they annihilated my armies. I have conquered Rome for Islam, and I have retaken Jerusalem for Christ. I have plotted, murdered, schemed, fabricated, built factions, sent bribes, hired mercenaries, raised armies, raised children, murdered children, arranged marriages, taken lovers, banished prisoners, executed prisoners, shown mercy to prisoners, died childless and alone, died with far too many children holding power and claims to the throne, and so much more.If you approach Crusader Kings II as Risk with an annoying thing about people that you need to deal with every so often, you might have some fun, but you're missing out on the real game: Eugenics and Murder Simulator II. The game is totally not for everyone. It is NOT a game that people pick up quickly. But once you get into it, it's the deepest and most rewarding RPG ever made. It's about guiding a family through history, through the sinners and the saints, through the great kings and the terrible ones, it's about surviving all the multitudes of things that can go tragically wrong, and it's about the joy of crushing your enemies, to see them driven before you, and to hear the lamentation of their women.As you might guess, I'm a fan. It really isn't for everyone, but if you have the patience to get to the point where you can take control of your own destiny there's really no game like it.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Finally, a game that does DLC right.I came into this franchise a little after the Old Gods DLC was released. Intially, I just played the original game, since there's a pretty steep learning curve and  the base game alone has tons of hours of gameplay by itself. The great thing about this game is, it a fully complete and deep game no matter if you decide to expand or not. With that said, each expansion has brought a different flavor and experience to the gameplay that I hadn't even known that I wanted until I was playing it. Having played them now, I would not be able to go back to just the original game as is. Even owning this game for as long as I have, I still play it on a consistent basis.Some people argue about how expensive the game and all of it's DLC are.  CK2 goes on sale like, every other month (if not more). Pick up a DLC here and there (theres so much in these that you really will be kept busy by the features in each) for a fraction of the regular price. Half of the DLCs you can ignore, because they are mainly eye candy things - extra skins or shields. I wouldn't worry about those until you have all the gameplay ones in your library.And if all else fails, there's a great Game of Thrones mod.

												I remember when I had a family, friends, and a youthful figure. This game took all of that away, and gave me something better. Every day after school I sprint home to resume my Crusader Kings 2 journey, forging my dynasty to make it the greatest in all of Europe. My teachers tell me I will have to repeat the 8th grade, that my grades are slipping, I tell them to meet on the hills of Normandy where my dynasty reigns with an iron fist. My family has tried everything, whether it be cutting my computer cords, stealing my monitor, or turning off the power in our house; I always find a way to return to my beloved Crusader Kings 2. The first 200 hours of this game are a warmup lap, after you complete the warmup lap you realize you need at least another 600 hours to get the complete experience... After 800 hours, you cannot stop, and you realize this game has consumed your life in every aspect, but do you care? Of course not, because deep down you know that your real life doesnt matter anymore, only the lives of your characters in-game matter. Once you come to this realization, you will be at peace. I must finish this review now, my Chancellor has notified me that my liege lord is waging war, I must gather my troops and prepare for impending conflict. Farewell all, and pray for me.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Crusader Kings II involes complicated strategy: diplomatically and economically as well as in handling domestic affairs to prevent insurrections and dynastically to continue your family's rule. It is set in one of the most captivating and exciting periods in history, has a myriad of possibilities, and even shows complex webs of feudal relationships quite well. It is a game that may seem overwhelming at first -- but that initial overwhelmingness translates into much thought and variations later. As with Europa Universalis 4, I definitely recommend the game, but it needs its DLC, which can get quite expensive at times.

content:
Posted: January 27
												CK2 is not for everyone. The interface and "gameplay" are very dense. The game consists mostly of an interactive map and clickable menus and the buik of processing goes to the system simulating other characters' choices and movements alongside your own. I definitely recommend watching some of the thorough gameplay introductions you can find on YouTube before you buy, and then again as you learn if you want to have any idea how to progress in this game. I love it, but you may not. Pairs well with a nice Malbec.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												Finally, a game that does DLC right.I came into this franchise a little after the Old Gods DLC was released. Intially, I just played the original game, since there's a pretty steep learning curve and  the base game alone has tons of hours of gameplay by itself. The great thing about this game is, it a fully complete and deep game no matter if you decide to expand or not. With that said, each expansion has brought a different flavor and experience to the gameplay that I hadn't even known that I wanted until I was playing it. Having played them now, I would not be able to go back to just the original game as is. Even owning this game for as long as I have, I still play it on a consistent basis.Some people argue about how expensive the game and all of it's DLC are.  CK2 goes on sale like, every other month (if not more). Pick up a DLC here and there (theres so much in these that you really will be kept busy by the features in each) for a fraction of the regular price. Half of the DLCs you can ignore, because they are mainly eye candy things - extra skins or shields. I wouldn't worry about those until you have all the gameplay ones in your library.And if all else fails, there's a great Game of Thrones mod.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I thoroughly enjoyed this game.I mainly play the Game of Thrones mod and probably only have around 15 hours of the base game out of my entire 200+ hours. Even though they might have some of the worse forum policies I've seen so far, I still love the political intrigue that comes with the game. Dynasties rise and fall, nations conquered, etc. Shattered retreat has a mod that removes it from the game completely (which is good since I hate shattered retreat, mainly due to the fact that if an entire army is going to retreat they would be much less organized. Especially if 10-12,000 troops just died out of your 15,000. If anything the army would split and scatted randomly, not being much of an army anymore.)Although I do hope for an RPG with similar political intrigue in the future (hopefully Game of Thrones based with smarter AI) as that would be a game of dreams for me.Amazing stories can also be created in the game, and I love the changes in history (or the differences in the Game of Thrones storyline) that can be found throughout it all. It's all extremely satisfying and I hope for more great mods in the future.Although when Crusader Kings 3 comes out you'll probably feel like your playing the first Crusader Kings on initial release. PI has a thing for reverting to it's base stage and making you pay for all the cool and interesting upgrades from the previous games through semi-expensive DLC.At least it's not Train Simulator DLC.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2016
												Ever dreamed of cutting off your neighbourghs balls because he screwed your wife? Ever dreamed of then executing your wife and all your children so you can marry that hot hungarian princess and produce children with CLAIMS? No? just me? Anyway, this is Crusader Kings 2.Crusader Kings 2 is a personal grand strategy game by Paradox Entertainment, taking place between 769 a.D and and 1453 a.D (assuming you got the dlc). In between, you will form a grand Dynasty, backstab enemies, fight wars, ♥♥♥♥ing go crusadin and♥♥♥♥♥♥and hopefully rule the world. Or you might just die childless to the 715th byzantine revolt in the last 30 years.Unlike most other grand strategy games, ck2 works on a "personal" base, instead of a "national" base. What that means is, you are not the country of poophill, you are duke kevin II of poophill. This mechanic leads to a very interesting gameplay, where personal rivalries and intrigues, as well as the capabilities of the different characters play a major role. As such, it is fundamentally different from other grand strategy games, which is always welcome in my mind.Due to this personal system, the game also offers great variety on who to play. Wanna play a great byzantine emperor and reinstate the roman empire? You do you, go ahead. Want to play as a pisspoor eunuch, whose only way of dynastial survival is being cucked by his wife? If you're into that kind of thing, feel free to. The game has near limitless possibilities on who and how to play, and it will keep you entertained for hundreds, if not thousands of hours.The biggest contra of this game, however, is it's insane amount of dlc. Of course, most of them are not mandatory for an enjoyable experience (I for one recommend: at least get legacy of rome and the old gods.), but they do add up to an insane amount of money for one game. As such, you should grab this game while it's on sale. Stuff on sale is cheaper. Cheaper is better. You can spend more money on food that way. Or on your weird fetishes, but hey, i don't know anything about you.To come to a conclusion, I can fully recommend CK2 to anyone who's interested in a different take on the grand-strategy genre, to medieval history nerds of all kinds and sizes and especially to psychopaths who like cutting off other peoples balls or blinding them, just because he won a tournament against you (that's what you get, Patreikos).Happy Crusading, Deus Vult!

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												Crusader Kings II involes complicated strategy: diplomatically and economically as well as in handling domestic affairs to prevent insurrections and dynastically to continue your family's rule. It is set in one of the most captivating and exciting periods in history, has a myriad of possibilities, and even shows complex webs of feudal relationships quite well. It is a game that may seem overwhelming at first -- but that initial overwhelmingness translates into much thought and variations later. As with Europa Universalis 4, I definitely recommend the game, but it needs its DLC, which can get quite expensive at times.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2016
												I thoroughly enjoyed this game.I mainly play the Game of Thrones mod and probably only have around 15 hours of the base game out of my entire 200+ hours. Even though they might have some of the worse forum policies I've seen so far, I still love the political intrigue that comes with the game. Dynasties rise and fall, nations conquered, etc. Shattered retreat has a mod that removes it from the game completely (which is good since I hate shattered retreat, mainly due to the fact that if an entire army is going to retreat they would be much less organized. Especially if 10-12,000 troops just died out of your 15,000. If anything the army would split and scatted randomly, not being much of an army anymore.)Although I do hope for an RPG with similar political intrigue in the future (hopefully Game of Thrones based with smarter AI) as that would be a game of dreams for me.Amazing stories can also be created in the game, and I love the changes in history (or the differences in the Game of Thrones storyline) that can be found throughout it all. It's all extremely satisfying and I hope for more great mods in the future.Although when Crusader Kings 3 comes out you'll probably feel like your playing the first Crusader Kings on initial release. PI has a thing for reverting to it's base stage and making you pay for all the cool and interesting upgrades from the previous games through semi-expensive DLC.At least it's not Train Simulator DLC.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2015
												I cannot explain what is so fascinating about this game.  Is it the alternate history?  Is it the dopamine hit I get when I reach a goal, or survive one more year?  Whatever it is, I find myself thinking about the count of Udonen, or the king of Georgia or whatever dynasty I happen to be playing.  A lot.  Even better, it loads fast, and if you only have 15 minutes?  No problem.  It is great for short bursts.Drawbacks:  you can sometimes get stuck in a situation where you can do almost nothing, except max out your game speed and wait until your situation changes.  This can occasionally lead to boredom, but it is a small portion of the game.

												I personally love CK2 and I can highly recommend it to anyone who loves strategy games. I enjoy it more than both the CIV and Total War franchises. The game is quite difficult to learn and can feel daunting for the first few hours but then it becomes a blast. Moreover, the Game of Thrones mod for this game is absolutely brilliant and is a must play for any ASOIAF fan.

content:
Posted: March 12
												I bought the game 3 days ago and I have 45 hours in it so far.. This game is so addictive. I much prefer this game to similar games such as Europa Universalis IV, especially when you bundle it up with all of the DLC.I can't recommend this game enough, it is so complex and intricate while being exceptionally rewarding. Don't expect a military strategy in the vein of Total War, as Crusader Kings 2 goes beyond the scope of any Total War game. some people may find the combat lacking compared to games like Total War etc. However these are completely different types of games, which some people just don't get. Combat comes down to size of force, composition of units, commander abilities, terrain and other modifiers. You don't get direct control like you would in Total War etc.There are so many different mechanics at play all at once. You have the Feudal system, where you're trying to please your vassals and build relationships with them, while you're trying to protect and enhance your dynasty, all the while stopping plots on you or your family, you're trying build claims on land to justify an invasion and you're setting up an Anti-Pope because the Pope excommunicated your uncle... Seriously when it all comes together it is both mind-boggling and fantastic.If you've always wanted to Marry your mother and imprison your father while waging war on your illegitmate half-brother.. well now you can. And it's brilliant.

Posted: July 15, 2014
												If you've ever wanted to RP as a 63 year old queen of Ireland who goes on late night romps with a single guard through the muddy streets of her city looking to fight a pack of ruffians and (of course) winning the fist-fight all on her own, this is the game for you. Or if you've ever wanted to start a game, get bit by snakes a year in, and die without heirs, effectively ending the game, all of this being random and out of your control, this is the game for you. So much fun.
